review_body: Wonderful hotel in a delightful setting. Surrounded by a lovely garden with a stunning old three-tier pagoda, this hotel is a dream: great service, comfortable rooms, tasteful furnishings and, probably, the most comfortable bed I have ever slept in. Has a spa, and a pool, a few restaurants and could be a destination in itself. Much recommended.

Driving from Narita Airport, it took about one hour to arrive at Hotel Chinzanso Tokyo. There are ample parking spaces (up to 400) available and for guests staying a daily parking fee of 1,000 yen is charged. After a simple registration we were shown to Room 929, a Prime Deluxe King with Garden View.The room is very spacious, about 60 sq.m, with a sitting room having a large writing desk, a sofa and marble side table, along with a comfortable king-sized bed. There is a separate powder space with vanity, before entering into the bathroom with bathtub and a shower stall. The toileteries are also premium, from L'Occitane.As the hotel is famous for its garden, before getting too dark we went for a walk. The garden entrance is located on 1/F, and after coming out from the hotel, we walked down a U-shaped slope through the woods, and soon saw the Monument of Chinzanso, with the engraved words of Duke Yamagata Aritomo when he named Chinzanso in 1878.Crossing the beautiful red Benkei Bridge, there are 20 or so Rakan stone statues, representing some of the 500 rakan drawings by Ito Jakuchu, a famous painter in the middle of the Edo Period. Each of the statue is about 50 cm tall.Continuing there is the Koshin Stone Monument. Carved in 1669, it depicts the beliefs of the Koshin school of Taoism. In front there is the Yusuichi Pond. It was created when the garden was first constructed, with a gourd-shaped having a lot of big and beautiful Koi swimming inside.Further along there is a famous well called Kokosei, with the quality of the spring water being recognized as the best in Tokyo. Beside the well there is the 13-tier granite monument honoring warrior tea master Oda Yuraku, the younger brother of Oda Nobunaga, the famous military commander.Along the path we saw the statues of the seven gods of fortune. Ebisu is the god bringing business prosperity and fishing success, also serving as the protector of those who loves the sea, fishing and sailing, as evidenced by the fishing rod and sea bream he is holding. It is also interesting to see the staff preparing the raincoat for the gods on the day.Soon we reached the two buildings in the garden, one being the restaurant we were going for dinner on the night, Mokushundo. The restaurant offers unique iron-kettle and stone-grilled kaiseki cuisine, while the other is the historic Zangetsu Teahouse. Baron Fujita relocated the teahouse from a villa in Hakone and now is recognized as a Tangible Cultural Property.Continuing we passed the sacred tree, the oldest tree in the garden at about 500 years old with a trunk of 4.5 metres in circumference and 20 metres high, before seeing two more of the seven gods of fortune: Jurojin, the god of longevity, and Hotei, the god of luck.Then we came to probably the most famous monument in the garden, the historic Entsukaku Three-Storey Pagoda. Relocated in 1924 from a temple in Hiroshima Prefecture, this legendary pagoda is said to have existed since around the 12th century. Tests show that many of its materials date from circa 1420. During a major renovation, it was consecrated in honor of Kanzeon Bosatsu, the Buddhist Goddess of Mercy.Beside the pagoda there is also a stone lantern, dated to the late Kamakura period (14th century), and praised by many experts as a masterpiece of the Hannyaji style. Coming downhill we saw two other seven gods of fortune: Bisyamonten, the god of wisdom and bravery, and Fukurokuju, the god of fortune, wealth and longevity.Then right in front we saw the crystal chapel, in which the hotel is famous for, and no wonder it is a premium and popular place for weddings. The Gojo waterfall beside has a 'hidden passage' where one can see through the waterfall to the garden.Returning to the hotel building, we came across the last two of the seven gods of fortune: Benzaiten, the goddess of music, eloquence and fortune, and Daikokuten, the god of the five cereals.After wiping ourselves dry with the towels provided, we went to the lobby lounge Le Jardin for afternoon tea. Looking at the greenery while comfortably sitting in the elegant sofa and table, I had the Dessert Set (1,900 yen), enjoying a rich and tasty New York Cheesecake with Strawberry Ice-cream, and a cup of coffee.After a good sleep, on the next morning we went to the Japanese restaurant Miyuki for breakfast. With an elegant and traditional atmosphere, the hearty breakfast includes Salmon and Grilled Vegetable in Sweet Vinegar, Pickled Plum, and Small Dishes of the Day; Japanese Grated Yam; Boiled Vegetable Oshitashi; Simmered Eggplant; Grilled Fish of the Day; Rolled Egg Omelet, Grated Daikon Radish, Salted Cod Roe; Steamed Rice, Pickles and Miso Soup; and Fresh Juice.Another compliment I have is that the hotel concierge was very helpful in purchasing tickets for the recently opened Snoopy Museum, saving us the time later to queue up. Overall we were very satisfied of our stay in Hotel Chinzanso Tokyo, with spacious and comfortable room, delicious food, impeccable service and the really nice garden. It is worth every penny I pay for.Prime Deluxe Room with Garden View (including breakfast for two) - 68,460 yen

Some years back, I stayed at the Four Seasons Chinzanso, and though is was drenched in signature Four Seasons style and decor, something still felt off... but seconds after my arrival to The Hotel Chinzanso, that feeling of something was off... Vanished, and Hello Gorgeous.I stayed two nites to pick up some Sake, no that's not the reason, did you think I was crazy?After a long 18Hr flight from Australia [4 hour connection in Singapore] I decided to break up my air travel with two nites in Fabulous Tokyo. I began reading reviews right here on Trip Adviser and Thank You [Yorkieboy61] and his review along others, I decided to check it out, I already love the area.I arrived early morning, looking like I flew in Cargo [deep discount economy] all the way, and yet I was greeted warmly with big smiles... and it continued this way for 29Hrs. They must have taken pity on my because I was checked in, upgraded to a suite and shown to my room within minutes.My room was located on a high floor, and a great view of the city. The suite was large, and the bathroom even larger... well it seemed that way to my jet-lagged eye's. Plush towels, L'Occitane amenities and a great big ole king size bed, allowing me two perfect nites slumber... ZzzzzzI was in Tokyo this past November and holiday spirt was in the air, and my Centurion needed some action, so after a long hot shower and room service, I ventured out sightseeing and shopping, after all I needed Sake... The Hotel Chinzanso, [like the former FS] is an enormous hotel and I swear there were 1,000 weddings taking place or maybe a couple, so I stayed away from that part of the hotel, and though I heard the hotel had a wonderful Gym, [so so so sad I had no gym clothes packed ;-p] also an amazing Spa [I did my spa-ing in Australia] I can't wright anything about them or where they are in the hotel.I had four meals within the hotel, once at ll Teatro, once at Miyuki Shut-The-Front-Door amazing yum yum yummy... too bad it was on my last nite... and twice room service.I have not an ill word to write about this Five Star property, but should you stay elsewhere [shame on you] you have to dine here!Travel can be harsh, be kind to your fellow traveler and enjoy the world and its diversity.

review_body: So I was here on a short business trip . Hotel was nice , rooms reasonable size and well appointed in slightly old fashioned style. Staff is amazing and only too happy to help with anything you need in all areas of the hotel. Main downside for a tourist is this hotels location which is not close to any major centre. It’s a 10-15 minute walk from the nearest subway station that is not on a convenient line so going to any major location requires transfer(s). As such you might find taxis as easier but more expensive transport alternative. Otherwise a very pleasant stay !!

I stayed Chizabso 12/8/19 for one night with friends. The rooms are good size with nice view. Have very comfortable beds and good amenities. We had a dispute regarding restaurant's bill but the manager of restaurants was very corteous and solved problem quickly. I strongly recommend Chizanso.

We were upgraded to a room with a garden view. Try to book these rooms if you can, because the garden is one of the best features of the hotel. Our early December stay coincided with the Autumn foliage, and let me tell you, it was stunning. Our room was huge by Tokyo standards, the staff was nice but not intrusive. Nice little extras like maple baumkuchen, good coffee/tea, and L'Occitane products. The location is a bit away from the other tourist spots and we found this to be a plus, even if we had to walk a bit more and take a few more cabs. Overall, such a great value for the money.

Unforgettable experience with the most enthusiastic and kind staff. Rooms are not only spacious but clean. The gardens are an unforgettable experience, full of history. The restaurants are like a dream

Our stay at this wonderful hotel coincided with the end of a celebratory trip to mark a significant birthday. We wanted to stay in a Tokyo hotel which would give us a sense of occasion and this hotel certainly lived up to that promise.This is obviously a luxury hotel (replete with luxury hotel price tag) and the rooms, service and garden setting are all magnificent. It sits high atop a hill in Tokyo and the city views from our room were expansive and certainly gave a sense of place and a feeling of space. As others have mentioned, there doesn't appear to be a buffet breakfast, and the set menus in Il Teatro (the breakfast room) are a little restrictive. Of course, by the second day, we learnt to push things a little and ask for some cereal, which was of course not a problem. As we were slow to realise, nothing would be a problem here, because the hotel is so focused on giving great customer service. (Yoshinari Chinen was such a welcome face every morning at Il Teatro. What service he gave to us! Thank you!)And the service everywhere in the hotel, from concierge to wait staff, was everything you could wish for. Unfailingly polite, extremely helpful, amazingly patient.We only ate in the bar at night as our days were long and involved much walking and we only wanted a snack. The bar menu was small but lovely and caters for those less inclined to dress up or spend big. Be warned, the bar doubles as a cigar lounge but we were offered a seat outside in the entrance area and found it perfect to our needs. (The service by Tomaoki Oshino here was fabulous! He "got us" straight away and hence the reason why we went back on our last night.)Walking to the nearest subway was not an issue for us - you can take the pathway through the garden and then stroll along the river, or you can head down the hill (faster) to the busy street, where you also will find a 7Eleven and a Lawson's, in case you need a few supplies. What we didn't realise was that there was a bus stop outside the hotel which would take you in the opposite direction to the Toden Awakara Line, the last streetcar line in Tokyo. One of our must do's for this trip was to catch this streetcar, however we headed off via the subway and caught it from a completely different location, not realising it was up the road. You live and learn.This hotel proves that great service is alive and well. If you want to treat yourself to a lovely stay, you couldn't find a nicer place. Welcome to Tokyo, and welcome to true 5-star service!

I stayed in Hotel Chinzanso with my mother during the early October for four nights (including Typhoon Hagabis). You absolutely can say nothing negative about the service at this hotel - everyone I met on their staff was unfailingly polite, prepared, accommodating, and kind. We utilized a couple of the restaurants, mostly The Bistro because we wanted some Western food in addition to the Japanese food we had while touring. It was very good quality and variety. The location is a short cab ride to the subway, which was convenient, but we utilized taxis mostly so it was fine for our purposes. They handled the typhoon like champs - little to no interruption in services at the hotel. We felt very safe and cared for during that time due to the attentiveness of their staff. As a side note, we are Catholic and stayed over a Sunday, so we were pleased that the Seikiguchi Cathedral is literally across the road and walkable from the hotel. We highly recommend the service at this hotel - we had a lovely stay!

Spent a one night stay in this beautiful and grand hotel away from the busy Tokyo down town area. The hot spring facilities are very nice with a outdoor swimming pool. Food is good in both Western and Japanese restaurants. Room is huge with good city or garden view.

A truly fantastic hotel. Everything was fantastic. The staff was outstanding, the best service I ever experienced after 30 yrs of International travel. This hotel is better than other great hotel like Atlantis in Dubai, the service is just perfect. The Conceirge service was exceptional, provided many useful advice and made our vacation a better one. Spacious rooms, big bath room, amazing garden, nice restaurants, great spa with hot tub in the garden.

On our way home after a week in Japan and the first four nights we spent at Chinzanso and it was a fantastic stay. My son had his birthday close to our stay and we were upgraded to a room on the top floor with a nice view, and the staff came with birthday cake for him. The hotel itself is a true 5-star expirience but what really sticks out is the service level from all the staff. Since Tokyo is such a spread out city and you anyhow need to take subway or train to get to many places the location was good and only a 10 minutes walk to the closest subway. The Japanese garden with temples are really beautiful and they have a great spa/pool area where we tried Japanese hot bath.. THANKS for making our stay to a memory for Life.

This is overwhelming. Hotel where everything is excellent, highly recommended. The park is amazing like the history. The staff is humoristic, remembers earlier visits and keeps wheels turning smoothly.

I highly recommend this hotel. It is situated in a high end area in a park like setting and everything about it is stunning. Our suite was excellent, service and attendance levels top class. It is easy to access all areas in Tokyo via the nearby Metro.

We had a wonderful lunch at the beautiful hotel garden. The meals were so tasty and everyone was so nice and helpful. The hotel looked shiny and new and we even saw a magnificent japanese wedding at one of the halls.

Beautiful location in a park – oasis of tranquility. A wonderful and quiet place for a stroll. Staff is friendly, welcoming and knowledgeable. Our room was very spacious with a large bathroom and various luxury bath and shower items.Thanks to the large luxury beds we slept well. Full breakfast (various choices, such as Am breakfast, Quick breakfast, in restaurant Il Teatro.Delicious fresh fruit juice, wide choice of hot sandwiches, various types of jam and egg dishes. Everything you wish for.Dining in The Bistro restaurant and the – Fuji hot lavastone Grillrestaurant (in the garden) is also a must, where delicious meat and fish are served.On request,staff gives us many suggestions and shows us the way to visit various museums and theatres.If we have to give one negative comment: our stay was too short.If you're looking for the perfect hotel for a business or private stay:We highly recommended Hotel Chinzanso Tokyo

The hotel had an amazing lobby with beautiful Christmas decorations and the garden was huge and lovely.We were oddly assigned to a room on the same floor with the wedding banquet halls. Staff were also actively blocking us from taking a look around the swimming pool and gym area which i felt was pretty rude.

This is a vast and impressive hotel, opulent even, and the staff couldn't be more courteous and friendly. They will go out of their way to make your stay as pleasant as possible. It's out of town in a more residential area, with a school and a cathedral nearby. However, within a ten minute walk is the metro station Edogawabashi which is the gateway to wherever you want to go in Tokyo. There's a bus stop across the road from the hotel, too, which is useful. As lovely as the hotel is, it's expensive to eat there. Within short walking distance are several small supermarkets, a Domino's Pizza and a Pizza Hut. On the last night we discovered a row of restaurants close to Edogawabashi metro which was a real find. The Hidakaya in particular was amazing - great food and for four people, including two beers, it was £18.

My second visit here. Amazing big rooms by Japan standards. Location is not the most convenient but the property is beautiful. The grounds at the back of the hotel house a wonderful Japanese garden that is a treat in itself. The concierge, front office and staff in general are so polite and warm and helpful. Overall a great stay.

This is a fantastic hotel if you like serene places and very quiet, comfortable surroundings. The staff is beyond helpful and speak excellent English - they were kind and very friendly. Many kudos to the staff, every on the property treated us like family and I felt welcomed and honored every time I made eye contact with anyone. After long travel this was so refreshing! The property itself is lovely and well maintained. The garden is a rare gem. This is no "simple garden" but holds history. This is a luxury hotel and the price shows, but for me it was worth it!Final advice, getting from Meijro terminal to the hotel with 2 people and 4 suitcases was a disaster. Taxi's don't accommodate this, and the buses don't either. We walked 30 minutes with our suitcases to get to the hotel. Knowing what I know now - I would called Chinzanso hotel and asked them to send a larger cab for me. Alternatively I would take a cab there (leave spouse and bags at terminal) and return with a larger taxi. Hope this helps!

Referred by a Japanese friend and we like it here so much that if u like to visit Tokyo n wanting to escape from the crazy crowd, here is living a cultured Tokyo-er plus a few hundred years old garden like Kyoto right outside my windows... the surrounding is just full of museums n vintage places like nowhere else can be found in Tokyo. Service is exceptional, room is super generous in space n food is great with restaurants hiding in the Japanese garden.Location is good, still very down town with JR Station is 200m walk away down the slope.We r lucky that it’s fireflies season n u get to see the luminaries at night.We r probably the only Chinese couple there n everyone is pretty much Japanese locals. We love it here n will come back for sure.

Ex Four Season Tokyo. A bit old but in general well preserved. Overall nice with some flaws.pros:- Nice location in plush gardens. Not too many rooms, does not attract loud tourist crowds or large airlines' crew for layovers- big, quiet and well appointed rooms. Nice views- very polite service and staff (rather common in Tokyo)cons- frequent wifi disconnections or throttle issues on floor 12, made very difficult to work at times- not very close to roppongi, shibuya etc. , expect to invest quite some in taxis - on one occasion found 1 cockroach in the corridor

Enough can not be said about this hotel. From service to environment and gardens, this place is serenity in a city. Every ‘T’ crossed and ‘i’ dotted in the room amenities themselves. Bathrooms stately and updated with LOcctaine toiletries.The only thing that was a small give ... was the location a bit removed but this is why we stayed here for buffered peace amongst the bustle of Tokyo. Close enough, but will pay more in terms of transportation timing and taxis.

This is a luxury hotel with large rooms, luxurious bathrooms and a great view. It's quiet and located in a beautiful park. A great place for a wedding. Although it is a haven in busy Tokyo and has impeccable service, it was not ideal for us.Breakfast is NOT buffet style which would have offered a selection of items to appeal to all travelers. When I ordered the continental selection and my husband had eggs, they brought one basket for both of us without toast. When I requested toast, they took the basket away, replaced its content with barely toasted white bread and 2 small Danish. We were shocked because this is not up to such a fine hotel's standard. The wonderful view of the garden and the tasty juice did not make up for it.The hotel is quite a hike down the hill to the metro station and reasonably priced small neighborhood restaurants. Our travel agency had booked us there. We would have chosen a different location. But it is certainly a very fine luxury hotel.

Classic and stylish hotel. Well equipped and spacious rooms. Very attentive staff. Good choice of restaurants on site. Beautiful gardens. Popular wedding venue at weekends. Quiet neighbourhood but still accessible to the rest of Tokyo.

We were tardy with our trip planning for the busy cherry blossom season, and picked this hotel to avoid paying more outrageous prices elsewhere. Very glad we "settled" for it. On arrival we were impressed by the spaciousness of our room, the large and well designed garden, and the immaculate facilities. Walking to the Y12 metro station along the river turned out to be a spectacular experience, as the cherry trees lining the river were in full bloom. The location is somewhat off-center but manageable, with 5 subway stops to the Imperial Palace. We would definitely go back to this hotel again.

What we had:King room, garden view. Cost about $650 AUD per night including breakfast.What we liked:Room is big for Japanese standards;Room is very nicely appointed with a huge bathroom;Hotel is tastefully done;Free use of pool etc;Extensive gardens (Our favorite part) with some restaurants in them;Soba restaurant which is actually good value;Breakfast - probably one of the best Japanese breakfasts we've had;Nice staff;Outside area is quiet and pleasant with more gardens nearby. Not so much:It is a fair hike to get there from Narita airport- probably 2 hours;Most restaurant prices are a bit over the top. Set menus look good but a lot of food.Summary:The pro's far outweigh the con's. After a major disappointment with Tokyo Station Hotel last year, we have found a new favorite.

We were so delighted with the superb service at this hotel. The amenities were plentiful. The gardens lovely. Nothing was any trouble and all extras were thought of. An easy cab ride to anywhere. Very quiet, comfortable and luxurious. Very spacious rooms. The staff are just amazing. Very good value for money.

Nothing was overlooked. It was a complete pleasure to stay in this hotel. The staff were exceptional.The rooms were very spacious as was the bathroom. Slightly far out from city centre but worth the effort of travelling back to such luxury after a day of sight seeing

Luxury does not equal to class. I have been to a few luxury hotels that are unfortunately classless. Some would expect a lot of tips for just doing their job description, nickel and dime on service charges etc. Hotel Chinzanso is the opposite. It sees going above and beyond as a requirement, like its simply what it is supposed to do. Not to mention all the small but sweet touches, such as a hand written welcome note from the manager, boiled hot water for tea and a box of snacks, a hand folded paper crane for good luck, as well as a local cellphone for each room’s guests to use during their day trips free of charge. And did I mention the property itself is just beautiful. The garden is of course gorgeous, but all the decorative antique items placed throughout the hotel is equally worth looking at. The only “downside” is the location. It is in a residential neighborhood; so unlike my friends hotel which is located at the heart of Ginza, it does not have any convenient stores or many cool and popular restaurants by its door steps. The hotel itself has a number of restaurants. We have eaten at a couple of them and they are pretty tasty. But their prices are at higher end and some requires advanced reservation. I feel for the same prices, you probably can find sth even better somewhere else. It is also a 10-15 minutes walk to the nearby subway station. However, if you mind the walking, taxis are always waiting right outside the hotel lobby. Because the hotel is centrally located, taxi fairs to most Tokyo major attractions are relatively reasonable.

This hotel is amazing.clean hotel with superb service and very beautiful garden. the minus point is the hotel locate in the hill so when you go to edogawabashi station (the nearest station) is ok but when you come back need extra energy. but you can choose more flat walk via edogawa park. But in the front hotel there is 61 bus stop so you can use this transporation

This Hotel was our first Japan experience, we will remember forever ! Welcoming staff, ease of check in at a busy time was made effortless. Attention to detail unsurpassed. Older style which we appreciated, fresh flowers, great food in all the restaurants. If it is refurbished I imagine the cost to rise, great value. Our spacious room had a Garden view, was a highlight, a very historic garden was wonderful to relax in, obviously has been a very dry season but it has been managed well. If you are there at the optimal period the Cherry Blossom walk right outside the door ! amazing. Felt like a local here. Thank you Hotel Chinzanso staff.

We travelled around Japan for 17 nights and this was the worst night’s sleep I had all trip (and at one point I stayed next to a railway line!)We basically splurged on our last night in Japan and decided to book a plush hotel as a special treat.Anyway we arrived at 3.30pm. The room was supposed to be ready at 3pm but we were told we would need to wait 5 minutes for housekeeping to finish. I know it’s a silly thing but at £265 a night you don’t expect that.Our room was large and really nice but the hotel exudes a sort of faded grandeur. All marble and mustiness. Apparently it is due a refurb in June 2019 and it needs it. We decided to head straight down to the spa. By the time we got down there after all the check in faff it was 4.45pm and we were told the pool closed at 6pm. So it meant we had spent a load of extra cash for spa passes that we could only use for an hour (it opened again at 10pm for two hours but we had show tickets). The spa itself was really nice though and had loads of toiletries to use in the ladies which felt luxurious. The outdoor sauna was lush! We went out that evening via the garden entrance and when we returned, it had been locked up. No one told us it closes. It meant we were walking in circles around Tokyo at 12.30am trying to get home.When we got to bed, we went to sleep straight away. We needed to be up at 6am to leave for the airport. However we were kept awake pretty much all night by what sounded like a muffled alarm beeping. We checked everything in the room - that the phone wasn’t off the hook etc and the only thing we think it can be is the lorry yard that our room overlooked and the poor insulation. On top of that, every half an hour there were loud creaky squeaks of what sounded like a cart being pulled around and loads of banging. It was awful, I didn’t sleep a wink.Another thing is its location. It’s a good 15 mins walk from the subway and we found it took ages to get anywhere as it is on a really awkward line. I wish we had saved our money and gone somewhere else. Oh and finally, this was the only hotel which made you pay the full booking cost if you cancelled within 14 days. Every other hotel and guesthouse (we stayed at another 5) offered much more flexibility and allowed you to cancel for free up to 48 hours before. The only thing about the hotel that’s great is the posh toiletries you get and the beautiful garden. The staff are pleasant. I did complain about my stay but the language barrier was an issue and the guy was really dismissive.

Chinzanso has a beautiful garden, but not many cherry blossoms except Hayazaki Sakura in front of the entrance. As she enjoyed them very much, she wanted to show them to me only a few days later. But when we went, the flowers were half fallen. It’s hard to hit the right time to enjoy cherry blossoms.

Attended a conference, and our rooms were secured here. This is is definitely one of the nicest hotels that I have stayed in. From the concierge greeting me on arrival, to check-in and check-out it was impossible to find better service. I got upgraded to a garden facing view and I have to say that it was simply idyllic. The rooms are spacious and impeccably clean with l’Occitane toiletries - top notch. Free water every day, Nespresso machine and pucks, free wifi and best of all - pure serenity. I also used the concierge service for stamps, airport bus and restaurant recommendations - again excellent service. I had breakfast at the Hotel restaurant il Teatro - very generous servings with freshly squeezed juice and coffee to your liking (I had a strong cappuccino - very nice). One night I ate at the Bistro with a few colleagues - great food and very reasonably priced. Can’t wait to return to this Hotel. Very good value for what one gets.

Hotel is very luxurious,has everything you need. My room was very specious, 9 restaurants on site, staff are very helpful. Very pleasant stay during business meeting, hotel staff accommodated all needs.

Loved everything about this hotel. The service was fantastic. The bar was nice and teh gardens were beautiful. I got food poisoning of epic proportions (not from there) the night before I had to check out. They were very kind to let me stay well passed check out time to recoup my energy. Not much of a surrounding area, and must be a savvy traveler in order to go into town.

review_body: First experience in a luxury hotel in Tokyo. Located within the compounds of Chinzanso gardens the hotel offers luxury rooms, restaurants, and a spa/onsen within the compounds. Breakfast of either Japanese or Westerner, food is very tasty and the attention to detail is impressive. The hotel is a bit of a walk to the nearest train station, Family Mart or outside restaurants but this is the concept of the hotel - isolation and quietness within busy Tokyo.

The hotel itself is the definition of luxe in Tokyo. Old school and very large rooms by Tokyo stds.Service and food were excellent. The garden is nice but I don't know what the fuss is about.Location is another issue altogether. Located in a quiet suburb and near Waseda University, it is quite far from the main thoroughfare. It is great for business purposes, but less for recreation. Took to walking 20min to Ikebukuro every evening as the weather was nice in mid Jan.

Pros:GardenVery large rooms and luxurious bathroomNice toiletriesRobes and Japanese pj'sService was above and beyondStunning view from a city view roomCons:Far from Subway, plus the closest station is not convenient.Soba restaurant's service was not goodHave to pay extra for pool No buffet breakfast, only a la carte

I really liked out stay at Chinzanso. We stayed in a suite room and my husband was very impressed with a large room and luxury bathroom. There is a beautiful Japanese garden and it is such a treat to walk around. It is a little far away from the subway station, but it is worth to stay at this special hotel. They have a shuttle service (about $30) to the airports which is very convenience for tourists. I would stay here again if I go to Tokyo.

I had the most enjoyable stay. Prior to the holiday, the concierge were superb in promptly managing my various requests including restaurants and taxi transfer from the airport. They additionally professionally managed various last minute reservation changes in an efficient manner. They additionally had no hesitation in accepting our delivery of our mobile Wifi and ensuring that it was ready in our room on arrival. On attendance to the hotel, we were escorted to our room and advised on the key areas for further information. We were extremely grateful to be offered a prime superior room on the top floor which offered breathtaking perspectives of the Tokyo city skyline. I imagine the rooms overlooking the gardens are equally impressive. The room was clean and comprised of all the key amenities and equipment, including integrated plugs which accommodated a UK plug. The service team were polite and considerate during both morning service and evening turn down service. We additionally had breakfast and the occasional dinner room service. Service was rather literally to the minute (for pre-ordered breakfast requests) and was both tasty and presented well. The gardens were beautiful and made a welcome contrast to the busy central Tokyo business districts. We attended the hotel language class with the best service manager which was very helpful, particularly as there was limited conversational english in some parts. Overall-the attentive staff and well presented hotel environment were a large part of our immersion in the Japanese culture and contributed to an excellent stay. We are due to travel to Japan in late 2019-early 2020 with the main focus on Kyoto, however following our experience will aim to stay 3-4nights in Tokyo. I would certainly recommend the Prime rooms due to more space and the higher floors.

The hotel's luxurious lobby, artistic garden and attentive staff made up for the location of the place.However would recommend not making a booking via Expedia . I found that my booking (through Expedia) excluded use of the poolwhich is considered part of a spa facility. This made for an awkward encounter for my mum and I. On the first day I had told her to take a look at the unique pool before heading out on the first day. The counter staff at the fitness facility asked her for her room number (which she forgot), and he appeared doubtful that she was a guest, and said he needed to check with "security" before showing her to the gym area. Later on i went down and he also checked my room number before showing me to the gym only. I was not allowed to enter nor take photos of the empty pool area. I was pretty confused as the place was advertised as having pool facilities and i saw other people traipsing in and out in their bathrobes without being checked by the spa staff.

We have stayed several times. This is a luxury experience. Restaurants are authentic in every way. Gardens are just stunning...feels like a secret location...far away from the bustling of nearby Tokyo. Highly recommend!

We checked in after a 14 hour flight with two young children and immediately felt relaxed. This is a beautiful, tranquil property.Our room was very large and well appointed with a beautiful view of the gardens. After a very long day of travel we enjoyed the luxurious bath and shower.We dined at the soba noodle restaurant on property and had wonderful service and tasty food. The walk in the park was beautiful.After a good night’s sleep we enjoyed the pool and spa. This was truly a relaxing way to begin our vacation. Everything was well maintained in the spa and very tranquil. The onsen was a wonderful experience.The staff throughout the hotel went above and beyond to make us feel welcome. The concierge helped us navigate our first day in Tokyo. I wish we stayed at this property longer and look forward to returning soon.

review_body: Luxury is what this hotel is all about, and you’ll discover it as you enter the reception area and all throughout its buildings. Staff is highly attentive and will make every effort to make you feel right at home. Their beds, I must say, are some of the best I’ve slept in throughout my travels.Rooms are ample and well furnished. Behind the hotel is a really nice garden to take a stroll after breakfast.If I were to be really picky about this review, I would say that their Sunday Buffet menu is very limited as so is their a-la-carte breakfast menu. Althought, limited should not be interpreted as tasteless in any way.The hotel is located far from main tourist spots inn the city and about a 10 to 15-minute walk (downhill is going and uphill if getting back) to the nearest subway station.

Yes, the room, view, service and staff were beyond compare. Even so this service can be replicated with good leadership. However, what can’t be copied is the culture of Chinzanso-so. It is unique to itself and no other. If you want to experience the warmth of its people, the beauty of its history and even catch a glimpse of traditional Japanese wedding couples or perhaps art. This is the place.

We selected this hotel with my husband, because of the beautiful surrounding gardens, without big expectations of the hotel. We were so rong! The gardens are amazing indeed and you can really loose the sense of time walking around, but the hotel is very nice also. The outside modern building has a touch of old elegance inside, the rooms are quit spacious and comfort for a family of three, as we are, the bathroom appliances satisfy anyone’s demand. Good quality Face soap, face cleaner, toner, face cream. There is no need to curry anything with you. The staff is very helpful and polite and the most of them speak at least a foreign language. The hotel is close to the tube, a coffee shop and a few drug stores. The distance from the imperial palace isn’t fare, not more than 10 to 15 minutes taxi drive. I am really content with our hotel choice.

Our stayed at the Hotel Chinzanso coincided with one of the largest typhoons of the season making landfall not far south of Tokyo on one of the nights. With a 10 month old baby, we decided to stay around the hotel on that day. This proved to be a blessing in disguise as we were able to wonder around the hotel's beautiful garden during the day. With so much history, we loved exploring all of its artefacts around the garden. Our baby particularly loved saying "Hi" to the koi carps in the garden's pond.Once the winds started to pick up, we took full advantage of the hotel's facilities. We took turns going to the spa and indoor pool whilst our baby had nap time in our room. There were plenty of great restaurant options as well which made it easy for us to stay at the hotel for the entire day. I highly recommend the soba restaurant for anyone with babies - the soba noodle is handmade and a perfect option for baby weaning.Lastly, our room was very spacious with plenty of room for the cot. The view of the garden was fantastic as well (and a great way to watch the typhoon pass us by). The bathroom was also very big which made bath time our baby fun and easy. I particularly loved how the hotel provided us with a baby kit complete with baby shampoo, toothbrush, lotion and a cute little teddy bear.

We stayed at this most luxurious hotel at the beginning of our guided trip to Japan.This hotel is lovely.The staff are courteous and helpful.The rooms are large,furnished beautifully and the bathrooms spacious with luxury products It has the most beautiful garden which you must spend time in to fully appreciate itThere are multiple restaurants all serving good food but the afternoon tea in the lounge area is very good,served overlooking the garden in a very serene graceful atmosphere,which is much appreciated.Breakfasts were very good western with a good selection,a voucher system seems to be used and you can order up to that value or have a set type menu and obviously a Japanese breakfast is servedThis is a wonderful retreat after the busyness of TokyoThe subway station is about a 7 to 10 min downhill walk so obviously uphill on the way back.

One of these old glory hotels that succeeds in staying at an excellent standard of service and comfort. Great rooms with great care in service. Concierge also very helpful with great recommendations. Garden is Fantastic to walk around

I definitely will come back again to this hotel. Good size, good view, good staff, everything was awesome..! We really enjoyed walking in the garden. Also the breakfast buffet was great. The bathroom and the toilet was seperated.

My wife and I recently stayed at this hotel a couple of nights after arriving from a long international flight. This hotel is really a fabulous hotel, with a great personality, very charming and very relaxing. Our room had all the extras, two robes, a light robe and a heavy robe, top brand soaps, cream, shampoos, etc. The decorations are really very nice, fresh beautiful flowers, very nice couches in lobby area. The staff is over the top - just exceptional, very professional, couldn't ask for anything more. We have traveled around the world and this hotel is at the very top of the very best. We highly recommend this hotel you will not be disappointed.

The hotel is well constructed and probably at the past was one of the excellent in the city. The crevices is very good and willing to assist with every question that we raiseThe room is a bit “tiered “ but the main disadvantage is the distance from the “actions “ whether you looking for tourist attractions or you looking for shopping

Tucked away in a quiet little spot in bustling Tokyo is an incredible hotel with amazing service. After losing my luggage they could not do enough for me and that impressive level of service continues during my stay. The gardens and restaurants are incredible!

I am glad to be invited to there to attend my friends’ most important date. The hotel presented outstanding no matter food, wedding ceremony or service. I learnt a traditional Japanese wedding there is an amazing experience. You might admire the beauty of Tokyo beauty from there because the hotel is located in the middle of hill or garden.No doubt, their service is quite good.I believe all of efforts should belong to my friend because her decision is obvious right.這間飯店的位置很不錯，真的很適合舉辦婚禮或是環繞的樹林遠離塵囂的好選擇。 他們的食物也體現了日本職人的精神， 我沒吃到雷的食物。婚禮的過程真的讓我我感受到日本人的講究與傳統細膩的美。交通可以搭地鐵到 目日站轉公車上51吧（用google) 我有附上搭公車的地圖在出站後的對面左邊（地圖黃色）車票210 yen

This is a wonderful luxury hotel. The large garden is a delight. It has a waterfalls that you can walk behind, statues that are hundreds of years old, and a pagoda. It is in a very quiet area. And while Tokyo is known for tiny hotel rooms, this is not the case here. The hotel is a ten-minute uphill walk from the Edgobashi metro station. It is a little out of way from some of the more touristy areas, but not a problem.

The location was good and the hotel was pretty nice as well. However, the service was beyond good, it was excellent. Went there on our honeymoon and at check-out the staff handed us a note hand written and signed by 15+ members congratulating us. Needless to say we weren't expecting that, it was a great detail and was super appreciated. Highly recommended.

review_body: My wife and I spent 4 nights at the Chinzanso Hotel in August on our first time ever to Tokyo, which was perhaps the last great city we had never visited. We we charmed by the Japanese and the hotel. In terms of customer service, I.am not sure we have stayed in an equal. The unfailing courtesy of the hotel and of the Japanese in general won us over totally. The gardens were lovely. We liked the fact the Chinzanso was in a residential area. That said it was only a 20 minute to the subway and one could be in Ginza within 20 minutes anyway. Nearby areas were really great like Kagurazaka. The restaurants were pricey but then Japan is pricey (probably because they do not cut corners) and the hotel pricing was in line with the other premium hotels. We want to come back as soon as we can. A lucky nation.

We spent a few days at Chinzanso at the end of April and it has been a great experience again. The service is great and the food is an absolute treat whether you wish to opt for any of the restaurants or have your meals in the room. Make sure you get a room overlooking the garden as it is quite rare to have such a large one while in Tokyo. Hope to come again in fall or winter.

Beautiful hotel with amazing customer service. Everyone was extremely friendly and helpful. The location was a short walk from local train. The hotel grounds are beautiful. Our room had a view of the garden which was very nice.

Well this was my third trip this year to Japan on business and I now always stay at the Hotel Chinzanso Tokyo.Why, well the rooms are spotless and have everything you need .The main reason id the high service levels as nothing is too much trouble.The airlines left my luggage in Frankfurt and the hotel got me all the things I needed till the luggage arrived.They now know me by my name as I walk into the hotel which is a very nice touch and makes you feel very welcome.If you can pay a little extra do so and experience the very best hospitality in any hotel I have stayed in the world.

Perfect! With a 600 years old tradition Japanese garden of “Mountains of Camellias”+roomy English Regal styled room+Highest Standard of Japanese Hospitality Service. What more can one ask for? The perfect spot to stay away for busy, overcrowded centre of Tokyo, yet just a short taxi ride away from the CBD.

Stayed there for one night and the room was fantastic - 12th floor with excellent views of the city. Large (for Tokyo) and clean and felt very comfortable - the decor is very European and at one point I felt I was in London! Lovely 600 year old garden outside to walk around with many interesting old artefacts. Looking forward to returning again.

Loved every minute spent there, the room was very beautiful and clean, spacious, the staff was very polite and helpful. I would definitely come back. There was free Wifi everywhere in the hotel, there was a smartphone available in the room to help you with internet outside the hotel.

New hotel in park overlooking Tokyo. Large adn inviting lobby area with attentive staff. Rooms are deluxe and spacious with all modern fittings. Bathrooms particularly inviting. A little bit off the beaten track and a bit of a trek to the subway, but good location neverthelss. Very quiet and relaxing for the busyness of Tokyo

Got married recently, and friends give us as a present 1 Night stay in the Hotel.The Room very very nice, wide and with a well equipped bath/shower room.Garden is very beautiful, and even by early july you can still see fireflies at night under a small bridge. Also it has a biotope to see fireflies closer. The Ilumination is also very nice.Staff is very attentive and friendly, and had a lot of preparation for us. Aside, the High Evening Tea is very delicious and also the western breakfast.Its a very enjoyable and unforgettable place to stay. Very recommended.

We had decided to stay at the chinzanso at the end of our 2 week Japan trip. We had already done most of our touring of Tokyo during the first segment of our trip, so decided to stay here for a slightly different experience, as it is not in a central location and the subway is a bit of a hike.It turned out to be a great choice. This hotel has some on that old world charm, but fully modern conveniences. The staff is super attentive when you need them. The rooms comfortable and clean. We were able to get connecting rooms at a reasonable price for Japan, as we were traveling with our 2 boys. The bathrooms were beautiful with very nice amenitiesWe were there for only 2 nights, so we did not get a chance to try the pool. We did roam around the gardens a little.We had dinner at the French restaurant- although expensive, they offer a deal for staying guests. They also have kids menus if needed. And the food and service was excellent.We also had breakfast-which was also very good. The afternoon tea looked very nice, and they do offer some experiences which we did not have time for.One of the best things-was the free phone they offer in each room. Since we were at the end of our trip we had to return our pocket WiFi and with this phone we were able to navigate our way around as usual (why doesn’t everyone offer this?)We would highly recommend hotel chinzanso for an off the beaten path experience.

Every thing about this hotel is simply amazing !! From the front door staff - to the rooms - to the grounds the hotel is built on - along with the city of Tokyo it self !! - everything is brilliant !I would 1000 percent recommend anyone who wants to experience Japanese hospitality at its very best they must stay at this hotel!

This hotel is an amazing property. The room was very comfortable. The spa was exceptional. The hotel has a lovely Japanese garden. The service was excellent. It is conveniently located near a subway stop.

Slightly far from downtown Tokyo, but worth the money for its luxurious, full service 5 star hotel. We stayed at the suite which offered gorgeous views, spacious room and bathroom, and quality amenities. In the room was a cell phone rental (included in price), which was very helpful.Staff are all professional and friendly. The garden is beautiful- wake up early and go for a walk before the crowd. The only downside is that it is kind of far from the nearest train station so cab is recommended... but that's why they have a huge garden in the middle of the city! Highly recommend this place for a few nights if you're not on a budget travel.

The Hotel Chinzan-so offers what can only be called "old-world service." The concierge desk is very helpful and extremely friendly. The rooms were very comfortable. Relatively reasonable rates can be found for this hotel. The only negative would be that access to the pool and spa area is not included in the rate, and is a fairly expensive $40 per day per person.

Really great five star hotel, took my mother here being her first trip overseas. We loved it, my mother loved hotel staff made her feel special and royal like. Closest station is only few minute cab ride, but well worth it - quiet area away from the hustle bustle but that is only ten mins away. The gardens are amazing, so it the hot spring, pool and jacuzzi. I'll be back next year!!

This hotel is definitely worth it for its price. It's located on a hill about 10-15 min away from the station so you will end up either taking the taxi a lot or grumbling about the hill, but the views, cleanliness and spectacular lobby area will take you away. Compared to other 5* hotels in central Tokyo this one comes up at a very reasonable price.Breakfast was fairly standard for a 5*, but I would recommend having it in the comfort of your room with the views of the garden. The staff do what they can to help you and it is perfectly set up for groups and events.

So far so good. Here with my company colleagues. 10 mins walk to train station. 5 mins to a convenient store. There is a free smart phone in the hotel during your stay. Breakfast is set meal either Japanese or Western. Tried the Western breakfast, was good.

It was my first hotel in Japan. Amazing beautiful, clean and elegant.We were a part of a group traveling in Japan. We came to the restaurant pretty early.The waiter was polite but did not understand any word in English at all. It was not a buffet breakfast, waited for a poor fried egg for 25 minutes! We almost missed the bus of our group...

This hotel is amazing. The staff was very friendly and will ing to give suggestions. We went during cherry blossom season and their gardens had spectacular views and themed tea time. Our hotel view of the city was wonderful. Overall I would say that the hotel is pricey, but worth it for the experience

The greeting and escort to the room from Concierge Andre set the tone for an amazing stay. The hotel does not do laundry - necessary after a 12 day tour. No problem. Instructions given to a nearby laundrette - 200 yen for a wash, 100 yen for a dry. Soap powder from the drug store next door - we left the remainder at hotel reception for the next guest. Room on floor 11 had sensational view of Tokyo, was super comfortable, classy and full of little touches. High end restaurants and bar were expensive but food and service exceptional - we could afford two visits. Nearest station was Edogawabashi - a 15 minute walk - very minor drawback. Glorious Hotel Garden steeped in history (Chinzanso = Camellia) wonderful to explore. Hotel up there with Fairmonts in Banff and Lake Louise. A major highlight of a 21 day trip. Better than 5 stars! Sekigushi Bakery on way to station - from front exit - local favourite and great for breakfast.

We adored our 5 nights at this gorgeous hotel! The rooms are so spacious and bathrooms are gorgeous! Nothing was too much trouble for the staff.It was so perfect as we were travelling with our 2 year old.The grounds are so beautiful and we loved our walk through the gardens every morning. There is also a sweet little park just down the path along the river with slides and swings.We were happy to be a bit further out and just take taxi's or walk along the river to the train or tram station. The staff are wonderful! Breakfast was amazing, room service was great and we loved out bbq dinner in the garden restaurant.My only slight sadness was that we couldn't use the pool with our 2 year old. Its only open to children older than 4years old. But it's not a deal breaker at all. We will definitely stay here again when we visit Tokyo again! :) Highly recommended!

Well I had not heard about this hotel before but it is great to stay, the attention at the front desk cannot be better, Wi-Fi speed is good maybe far from lots of places but there is always ways to transport around Tokio.

This is one of the best hotels we’ve ever visited, certainly amongst our top five. Stylish, beautifully appointed, with large leafy grounds, a pagoda, waterfall and many species of camellia. The staff couldn’t have been more pleasant and Andre the director of guest services was helpful beyond the call of duty. On our next trip to Tokyo, this will most certainly be our choice.

Stayed here for two nights at the end of a two week trip in Japan. We were made very welcome and upgraded on check-in to a garden view executive suite. This is a fabulous spacious suite with luxurious design and an amazing view. The bed was really comfortable and the kimonos a perfect fit. As we arrived late from Nara we didn’t really spend much time in the hotel. If you have the time to use the spa, pool, and gardens it would be a fantastic place to relax and get a bit of respite from the pace of the City. Unfortunately, we did not have the chance to do much at the hotel. This is a five star hotel so expect 5 star prices. The dining options are fine dining restaurants and are priced accordingly.The bar had the design of a gentleman’s club, but was warm and welcoming. I had some great Margaritas here and the complimentary bar snacks were first class.The hotel is easy to reach via JR Yamanote line and bus or taxi from Majuro station. Narita Express can be reached via Ikebukuro (c.1500y and 15mins from hotel) BUT not all trains stop here (only around 13 a day).The hotel is a short walk from a subway (shortcut through the gardens then follow the river path) but you will need to change to get to places like Shibuya or Shinjuku. Although there isn’t much in the area of the hotel I wouldn’t let that put you off staying here.

We were taken by surprise by the Old fashioned service, the confortable but luxurious deco, the view and the garden! Very child friendly room with a tub big enough for us all!Not super close to communications but you can take the bus to the nearestJR station.Good bed and sheets!
