review_body: My second time in 12 months in this hotel was again a real treat. They are extremely professional throughout, the room facing the garden is superb as is the garden (though I didn't realise that in fact they had less Sakura trees than Camellia bushes. One improvement could be the provision of a shuttle bus into town as the hotel is a bit remote. This would make a stay 100% perfect. Thank you again, Hotel Chinzanso.

Such welcoming staff from the moment we got out of the taxi to the moment we got back into the taxi 4 days later.Lovely reception staff. Helpful, warm, accommodating. Same to say about the cleaning staff who would stop what they were doing to smile and greet us.When we got to our room there was a long hand written card welcoming us and comgratulating us on our honeymoon, also two maple cakes. Room: very spacious, huge bathtub and separate shower. Lovely l’occitane toiletries. Huge bed. City view with buttons beside the bed to open and close the net curtains and drapes. Huge tv (though mostly Japanese channels naturally). Desk. Table and chairs and separate chaise long. Free phone: so on the desk was a mobile phone with internet. We could use this around Tokyo to google places and check google maps. A life saver. It gets wiped automatically after you leave and return it to its cradle on the desk. Food: I’m awkward enough with food. No meat or fish, and only cooked eggs as pregnant. We got the Japanese breakfast one day one. Lovely setting overlooking the gardens. The manager came over to help figure out what I’d eat. They brought me a big tray of Japanese food. All lovely and I ate my fill. Also roast green tea and juice. The next day we had breakfast in the italIan restaurant. They accommodated my food requests uncluding giving me a fruit salad off the menu. Such friendly and helpful staff!The gardens: we wandered around the gardens for an hour. They’re pretty and the fresh air was nice. Room service: we ordered a margharita pizza on the night we arrived. Pretty standard, it came on a table clothed table with glasses of water. Location: 10-15 minutes to the subway but it requires a bit of a treck up a hill. Not the best location but not the worst. Plenty of taxis waiting outside.Overall wonderful experience.

Arrived after at 11am after a 13h flight followed by a 2h ride from the airport. This makes it 4h before the "official checking time". Being told my "room is not ready". Really wanted to freshen up as had business meetings in the afternoon. Asked if any other room would be ready and they offered another one, same category, but I would have to pay the equivalent of USD 280 for the "4 additional hours", or, they would call me as soon as my room would be ready. Making them aware that I was part of a large group (> 200 people on a multi day business gathering right there). No impact. After noon time asked again for my room or any room, and they insisted "rooms are ready, but still have to pay USD 280 for the three additional hours, I would get mine by 3pm". Ridiculous. I asked that if I then check out at 7am (i.e. 5h before official check out time), if they would pay me back the difference, but they did not even get the irony of that. Short before 2pm I asked a third time for the room (remember, empty available rooms have been there with no claim for hours), and this time they had guts to tell me now it would cost me "only" USD 145 for this additional hour before "official check in time". Asked to speak to the manager on duty, and that was the manager duty already.... As a global business traveller with dozens of trips in a year, this is the worst greediest service ever seen by a front desk! Normally the review would be "terrible", but then again, it seems a bit unfair, because the hotel is really nice, great big rooms, immaculate cleanliness, excellent restaurant, and the rest of the staff truly took great care of every thing (although, comparing globally with hotels of similar standards, expect to over-pay 1.5-2.0-fold). Just the reception team and probably the management's greed spoiled the experience and need significant training or replacement.

Last weekend my wife and I and our son and his fiancé had the pleasure of staying at this wonderful hotel. This would have to be the most perfect hotel I have ever stayed in. The attention to detail and appointment of everything you require in a stay was catered for. The customer service provided by all staff at the hotel was excellent. We were accommodated on the 8th floor, overlooking a beautiful garden. The garden included a three storey pagoda and we were entertained by mainly garden weddings taking place while we were there. The hospitality we received from members of the Japanese community was also outstanding .

We stayed here for one night, only because we had points to spend. It is very expensive and the type of traditional luxury that you would expect from a four seasons. Brilliant garden with a good selection of restaurants and nice spa. Probably aimed more at a slightly older clientele.

An enormous hotel with 9 F&B outlets and 37 ballrooms, a venue for both business and tourist travellers. Rooms are gorgeously furnished in elegant design of old. The highlight of this hotel is it’s famous gardens which blooms Sakura during spring and has beautiful autumn colours in the fall. One of a kind

I have been to Chinzanso 3 times and valued it as one of the best hotels in Japan. Their spacious garden and precious onsen attracted me to come back. However, I have some complaints about my recent visit to Chinzanso— the onsen.First, the open-hour of the spa is too short, which opens from 8:00 am – 6:00 pm and 8:00 pm – 10:00 pm. At 8:00 am, the guests may be right at the restaurant enjoying their breakfast or just finishing it. Considering the guests are used to checking out from 9:00 to 10:00 am, though the official check-out time is 12:00 at noon, one has very limited time to use the spa. At evening, the spa closing at 10:00 is too early. Like our case, we finished our dinner in Mokushundo at about 9:00 pm, then we had to go to the spa with full bellies in a hurry.If the open hours can begin at 6:00 am and end at 12:00 midnight, that would be much more convenient for guests.Second. We visited the hotel during Chinese New Year holiday, and the guests from China mainland were more than usual. When I went to the spa, the gentleman at the reception showed me a guide for how to bath in an onsen in simplified Chinese characters, which I have not experienced during my previous stays. After taking a glance at that guide, I nodded to him. The gentleman seemed suspicious about my understanding of the guide and showed it to me again. At that moment, I told him: “I have been here for three times.” and he breathed a sigh of relief.I understood that some guests from PRC might not be familiar with the onsen manners, and I also respected that this gentleman was doing his job. However, for me, a guest having visited more than 60 Japanese onsen ryokans, it felt kind of insulting at that moment.The Hotel managers are better to know that: Chinese-speaking people are not all from PRC, and most of them know the onsen manners well.

I thoroughly enjoyed my stay at this hotel. Was looking to entertain some business associates and found the quiet, spacious environment, beautifully appointed suite and private dining rooms the perfect solution.

The rooms are big with comfort rooms and has nice city and garden view. Price of the room is very expensive and may not be worth it if you are looking for a very good breakfast a day after.Breakfast is not buffet and has small portions of food only. Not recommended for budget travellers and for those who want to go shopping. Location is far from convenience stores or shopping areas.

First class hotel. Deserves every penny and all the accolades heaped on it. The park within the hotel compound (or is it the other way round?) is second to none. You’d secretly wish the park is bigger, then this place’d be PERFECT. Top tip: Book ahead if you want to dine in, they’re exceedingly strict on this.

We loved our stay at Hotel Chinzanso Tokyo. The staff went out of their way to provide a memorable experience. The highlight of our trip was the Samurai Experience. Truly exceptional. The food and the setting were exquisite.

Elegant and warm hearted reception after exhausting 27 hours of travel. Our clerk was a great comfort offering a sincere welcoming smile. Every whim or want met and then some. Even ordered breakfast from Front Desk while checking in! Housekeeping proved most talented removing an unknown stain from a wool dress coat. Well done and thank you again.Do not miss Yu Spa, especially the private massage rooms for couples. Serene, harmonious & memorable any day of the year while overlooking the waterfall. Our therapists provided professional five star attention to all the important details from aroma therapy selection presented ceremonial style to ending kindly with a fruit plate, hot tea and stress free.We enjoyed walking in the gardens (saw many stunning Geisha's being photographed) and the view from our room was outstanding. I urge all to read up on the garden history before site arrival for maximum appreciation. Keep a look out for the large black crow that guards the pagoda!Il Teatro offers guests an "un atteggiamento positivo." Having large windows and comfy seating, we stayed much longer than originally planned delighting in the ambiance and absurdly perfect service. Yes, the food is delicious too. Bravo e grazie bilione.The feeling of unity and peace within this location is born of the talented and unique staff who serve with pride. As beautiful as the orchid arrangements were adorning the lobby, Emiko and Manaka both added to our visit despite being far too brief. Now it is most important to give kudos to the Director of Guest Services who seems to be the magical ringmaster of my newest favorite oasis. Thank you for being you, so well indeed. Your energy and limitless talent are steadfast and appreciated around the globe.I will remain devoted to Hotel Chinzanso Tokyo.

The hotel staff were amazingly hospitable, friendly, and helpful. They were very warm in welcoming us when we arrived a little past 10 PM. The man at the front desk even gave my sister and I (we're 20 and 21 respectively) stuffed animals when he learned that we had just arrived from our hotel in Disneyland. The location of the hotel is not that convenient though, in my opinion. The walk to the nearest station will take you at least 15 minutes (if it's your first time navigating towards it and if you're a relatively slow walker like my family is).The hotel rooms are outstanding! We had connecting rooms, and they were spacious! The bathroom was really impressive as well, and had excellent amenities. The view from our rooms was also something to rave about! The windows were tall, and the blackout curtains were automized. We weren't able to check out the spa and the gardens (which were a total bummer!), but I hear they're equally impressive. I might book a room here again if I were to just want to relax. The proximity to the nearest public transport kind of let me down a bit.

We had a wonderful stay at Chinzanso during our last summer trip to Tokyo, for about a week. The place is a mix between Western (French mainly) and Japanese style. The rooms are spacious, very comfortable and nicely equipped. The food experience was delightful, from the popular chicken curry to the top notch Kobe beef cooked teppanyaki style. The room service was exceptional (service & menue). The hotel is set into a lush garden that includes an old pagoda, terrasses, restaurants and a famous walking path. Great spa and swimming pool; photo studio available for weddings or other celebrations (7-5-3, for example). Some areas are restricted and children are not allowed to come in (the Marquee bar, restricted hours at the pool). There isn't any kids club by the way. All in all it has been a wonderful stay during which we could enjoy the best service I have ever found in a hotel. Two things though could be improved in my opinion. First: the breakfast. One has three choices if I remember correctly, all served at different places: typical japanese style, mixed buffet near the lobby, or "à la carte" at the Italian restaurant. We didn't try the japanese one, but we had to eat at the Italian restaurant as the buffet was mainly prepared to satisfy the Chinese guests (lots of Chinese dishes: dumplings, soups etc). The "à la carte" breakfast was nice but it turned out to be more or less the same choice everyday. And second: the lack of transparency regarding the room rates. I asked for a late check out (leaving at 5:00PM) and the hotel actually charged me a full night, and at a much higher rate than previous nights. I didn't bother to argue or negotiate but I couldn't see why it turned out to be as such. I believe I should have talked to the original receptionist that had welcomed us upon arrival. Anyway, as I mentioned above, it has been an exceptional experience and we would be delighted to come again. Probably this coming spring.

I stayed in room 1016 with a view of Tokyo Skytree. The room was large and spacious with a comfortable large bed and panoramic windows. There was a large bathroom with separate room for toilet and both a bath tub and separate shower cubicle. The service was excellent and the staff spoke good English. The hotel is within easy walk to a subway station so once you check in and get your bearings it is easy to get around Tokyo with minimal expense if you have the Suica card. I stayed here for 3 nights before joining a cruise ship holiday out of Yokohama.

Highly recommend at least one night at this gorgeous hotel - make sure you get a garden view. It’s far from stuff but it makes for a nice respite from the pace of Shibuya/Shinjuku/etc. Spend a quiet night soaking in the heated bath and don your kimono and just... unwind. Walk the grounds in the morning and soak in the zen. The staff is incredible and really showcase the Japanese hospitality! Some other tips: if you want to eat at their restaurants you have to get reservations early or else its room service! And if you order room service stick to the cheeseburger - my girlfriend ordered the salmon and it was a portion for a mouse or some other small woodland creature (the only time we felt anything negative here). For lunch there is a wonderful organic cafe just a few minutes walk from the hotel, also highly recommended.

Wonderful hotel in stunning grounds. Stayed for one night - room was sizable and well-appointed. Big bathroom, even bigger bedroom. View of the grounds.Grounds allowed for nighttime walks, viewing the fireflies. Very romantic, very pretty.Good service, and lovely in-hotel spa/swimming/sauna facilities.

Beautiful room and hotel. The garden was amazing and the traditional Japanese breakfast was a great experience. Every single employee we encountered was kind and patient with us (we do not speak Japanese) Highly recommend!

Located in city center not far from Shinjuku. The hotel has this peaceful and quietness which relaxes you. Hotel is a classic European designed building, beautiful marbles layer in many places.There is a hot springs located on second floor with swimming pool. Breakfast can be taken in two locations (English and Japanese) set breakfast.Rooms are large and comfortable. I enjoyed every second of my stay. Especial thanks to Ms. Emiko Yago san for her hospitality.

Hotel Chinzanso is everything it advertises and more. I was so pleased with the service, the huge room, the Onsen (yes ... they have an onsen!! - rare in Tokyo), the restaurant, the gardens. Yes, it's a bit out of the way but the airport Limo does take you there. It's all plus for me and I would definitely return. It's now one of my 2 fav hotels in Tokyo - the other being right in town.

I love this hotel, weekday stay they have reasonable price.The hotel room is big, not like other Japanese hotel rooms are tiny small.The floor level we stayed has nice view at day or night.In Japan, most restrooms have heat seat toilets, that is the best part i love as a girl. The bed in the hotel room is just firmed right, let us have a great rest.This is an old 5 star hotel in north part of Tokyo. the transportation is not bad to take us around the city. behind the hotel building is a nice Japanese garden. you may walk with fresh air and full of green in your eyes. there is airport shuttle can directly drop off or pick up us in front of the hotel. I love this hotel, and will stay again next time.

We have just spent 4 nights at this hotel. Whilst it is a little bit out of the way there are shuttle buses and you can walk about 7 mins to the closest metro station. There are always lots of taxis parked out the front of the hotel. The staff were very kind, helpful and friendly; always so polite.We had a problem with our room being near a noisy service lift so they kindly moved us to another room with an upgrade to a suite.We were disappointed with the meals in the hotel so mostly ate out.The rooms are spacious and well laid out but furnishings are dated. Carpets in the hallways whilst clean look old and faded.We used the swimming pool which was nice but it is indoors.The airport limousine bus service stops at this hotel which makes it convenient to go to Haneda airport. I am not sure if they have the same service to Narita.The best thing about this hotel is the large, lovely gardens - they would be amazing in Spring and Autumn.

My wife and I wanted a true Japanese hotel on our stay in Tokyo September, 2017. Nothing against the Hilton or similar hotels (we like our comfort), but we didn't want to visit Tokyo (or Kyoto, see my review of hotel there) and stay in hotels similar to what we could stay in in New York, Chicago, LA or almost any large city. Or hotels similar to the ones we had just stayed at in China (a Ritz-Carlton, Wyndham Grande and Regent) The reviews of the Hotel Chinzanso struck a cord and, as it turned out, were very accurate. We were among the few Westerners at the hotel - it's clearly a favorite of well to do Japanese. The entire feel of the hotel is Asian, from the decor, decorations, wood, to art, including featured paintings by a local artist, The park in which the hotel is situated is beautiful, and reinforces the feel that you are truly in Japan, not Cleveland or Manchester or Sydney. That's not to say that the hotel lacks the features of a Western hotel -- it emphatically does. Our room was large, clean and comfortable. There are a couple of restaurants serving Japanese and Western meals, and as expected, service is first rate. We especially enjoyed meeting Andre, who is a gracious ambassador of the hotel directing guess services. He was helpful when we asked about a walk-about neighborhood that wasn't too far away that we would particularly enjoy. He pointed us to a pretty and active section close to where he lives. The hotel, as the reviews suggest, is not near central Tokyo. It's maybe 30 minutes away. But we figured out the subway system (it wasn't hard) and were able to get back to the hotel with no trouble. There is a hill to walk up, and I wouldn't recommend traipsing up it for the handicapped, but my wife and I felt it provided a nice little workout. We were delighted with our choice of the hotel. We've stayed in fabulous hotels from India to Vietnam to Paris, and this is the equal of any, and heartily recommend it to anyone who wants to experience Japan in Japan, not Houston in Japan.

Some aspects of this hotel experience were great whereas others were rather lacking so Ill try to be fair in this review.The staff (exceeding normal Japanese standards) were super polite.I had lunch in their French restaurant. Whilst expensive, it was top quality stuff.Room service, not so much.... around $80 aud for a tough burger and a salad... I know room service you pay a premium but you can get a better burger at 7 Eleven for a couple of dollars.I got the room on Agoda on a pre paid basis but they still slugged me with "hotel tax". Whilst only 200 yen I feel this rendered the advertised price misleading.I was offered an upgrade (for 10,000 yen which I declined) only to find I was upgraded anyway. Whilst it was great to be upgraded I suspect what happened was they sold out of standard rooms and knew they had to upgrade me anyway (meaning the attempted upsell was a bit disingenuous).Rooms were quite nicely done albeit they styling inspiration seems to have been my grandmas house. Although high quality fit out its looking a bit tired.The hotel backs on to a beautiful Japanese garden which is a lovely setting.The hotel is a long walk to transport and not convenient for accessing anything tourists want to see in Tokyo or the airports.

The hotel is beautiful as one would expect from a luxury hotel in Tokyo. But - it is the gardens - acres and acres of landscaped serenity - that makes this hotel exceptional. It is about 1/2 hour away from downtown Tokyo and the Ginza - and for some this may be a drawback - but it is more than compensated for by the views and the surroundings. The staff provide exceptional service - charming, helpful, incredibly efficient and still very discreet. Everyone you meet in the hotel treats you as though you are very special - client orientation is clearly very high on their list. This service attitude is something the west could learn. It makes the stay that much more special and leaves you wanting to return. Should I return to Tokyo this would be the hotel I would choose to stay at.

A friend and I went to have lunch at Miyuki. It was an excuse for him to discover the beautiful gardens of the Chizanso as well as the premises of the property which is one of my favorite in town. We had a fabulous experience, we could even be moved to a better table near the window and soak in the beauty of the gardens while enjoying our exquisite lunch menu. It has been several times I take people there and Miyuki never disappoints. The food is excellent and the service is very polite and friendly.

Tokyo is relatively expensive. We got a good deal on this hotel, approx. 270 USD (breakfast not included). Very very nice hotel, impressive, cozy, big room for Tokyo. Excellent service, fantastic surroundings (park). We were upgraded to a Park View Room without asking. Luxury-level.

What a beautiful experience! True perfection of Japanese hospitality in a traditional classic Japanese style western hotel. It's definitely much higher quality than all other western chain hotels in Japan. Garden is absolutely amazing and provide escape from hectic business city of Tokyo. Spa, restaurants, complimentary coffee lounge, beautiful interior of hotel and spacious room with elegant furniture was all fantastic. Definitely will go back. Worth every minute of it. In Tokyo, no other hotel has this kind of classic quality unless you want neo-modern, common trend worldwide.

Enjoyed my stay at this quaint and charming hotel. The welcome was warm and friendly. Customer service was top-notch. I did not have any issues or concerns as a solo female traveler. I even had mail upon arrival waiting for me which I was quickly made aware of. The room itself is spacious and the bed will make you reconsider getting up. I was so cozy in the room I had to balance spending time inside enjoying the amenities or doing what I traveled all the way from New York to Tokyo to do...cherry blossoms! I wasn't sure how difficult it would be navigating from the hotel but was pleasantly surprised. There's a train station at Edogawabashi that is quick into Tokyo station and all other points. The walk down the hill isn't bad at all but I did struggle a bit walking back up the hill. It's doable. Keep this in mind if you have disabilities or health issues. It's a steep hill. The room service and numerous restaurants were good as well. I enjoyed the hazelnut french toast. The garden, well words just can't describe all the things going on in this garden. Do yourself a favor and stay here. I have no complaints or criticisms. When I visit Tokyo again, I'd stay again.

New York City, New York

review_body: Chinzanso once was the resident of Yamagata Aritomo who is a military strongman of Meiji age, If you are interested in the history of Meiji Restoration, you shall not miss the spot.The recent visit to Chinzanso is my second time. The first time was in 2013 when the hotel was just out of Four Seasons System. There was a rumor that the Four Seasons gave up this hotel since the hotel was aged. When I visited Chinzanso at that time, it did seem a little bit old, but it was by no meant decayed. Instead, it was so elegant and majestic and just like an old time aristocratWhen I visited Chinzanso this July, I found it was still so classic and charming. The managing staffs took a good care of this old pear, and even punishing it brighter.The spacious room with a view of the garden which was already worth the rent I paid. One could hardly find a prime hotel with such a huge and beautiful garden in any metro cities like Tokyo.My package came with free SPA and free breakfast. I always enjoy their swimming pool and spa. The spa has the real Onsen water from Shizuoka, which is rare in Tokyo. Their breakfast was also enjoyable. One did not need to have a meal in a noisy buffet room but tasted fine Japanese or western style gourmet in a quiet dining room.We had a simple soba lunch at the Mucha-an. The meal is delicious, and the price is fair. Last time we had dinner at the yakiniku restaurant Mokushundo. Since I missed that dinner, this time I reserved a table before departing for Tokyo. Regrettably, I had to cancel the reservation since Japanese friends’ inviting for dinner at another place that evening. If you want to experience authenticly traditional Japanese style of elegy, Chinzanso will be your best and maybe the only choice in Tokyo. Next time I visit Tokyo, I will stay here again definitely.椿山莊曾經是明治時代軍事強人山県有朋的宅邸。如果你對明治維新史有興趣就不能錯過這個地方。這是我第二次到椿山莊。第一次是在2013年這家飯店剛退出了四季酒店集團。當時傳聞是因為飯店太老舊了而被四季放棄。不過當時我親身感覺是飯店有點老但絕非是在頹壞中。相反的，它是優雅而堂皇，就像個老貴族。今年七月我再度造訪時，我發現它依然是經典且迷人。管理人員悉心維護它，甚至讓這顆明珠更閃亮。寬敞的房間窗景是庭園景色，這個庭園就已值回房費。很難在東京這種大都會中找到一個有如此漂亮廣闊庭園。我買的組合包括免費的SPA 和早餐。我一直很喜歡他們的游泳池和SPA，後者是用來自靜岡的溫泉，這在東京是少有的。早餐非常好。你不需要在吵雜的自餐廳用餐，而是在安靜的餐廳裡享用日式或西式美食。我們在無茶庵吃了簡單的蕎麥麵午餐，味美而價格平實。上次來訪時我們在木春堂吃烤肉，令人懷念，所以這次出發前已訂了位。遺憾的是當天有東京的朋友在別處邀宴，只得取消訂位。如果你想體真正傳統日式的精緻，椿山莊會是你在東京最佳甚至唯一的選擇。下次再來東京，我一定還住在這裡。

In general, the service provided is ok. The room space is big compare with other hotels in Tokyo.However, the facilities are very old and the maintenance of the room is poor. One of my familiy member had a room with really bad smell though they were moved to another less-smelled room. I thought such rooms shouldn't even been saled to any guest at all. The toilet in my room had problem so I had to call somebody to fix it in the late evening. My parents' room closed to the lift could hear the machine noises when turned off the TV in the late evening. I dont think it should be rated as 5 star hotel according to the rooms provided.

Great hotel. A fifteen minute trek from Edogobawashi tube station. In the middle of a five hundred year old Japanese garden, with pools full of fish and waterfall. Great swimming pool and jacuzzi. L'occitane Provence toiletries.

The hotel was very calm and comfortable. The garden was great to walk around. They had historical statue of Buddha and sculpture. The restaurants inside hotel were Japanese style and Western style. Japanese food in the restaurant was rather salty. The hotel was located inside the Tokyo, but not in the center of the city. There were two hotels in Tokyo under the same name of Chinzanso. Therefore I have to find out the exact address of the hotel for taxi driver.

The hotel is being positioned as a 5*, and no doubt that some decades ago it were so, but now I would doubt that it would correspond to modern luxury traveller's needs. The location overall is not very convinient. The hotel is approximately 5-7 minutes in foot from the nearest subway station, but there's absolutely nothing interesting nearby, as it is a quiet residential area aside from the main attractions of Tokyo. The hotel has a belle epoche flare, but looks as it has never been refurbished since those times. In many aspects the hotel is outdated - not enough electricity plugs, and those available are hard to find and partly not working; old-fashioned design. Currently there is some refurbishment ongoing, so I hope they will rennovate it. The hotel garden is large and lovely and there are a lot of fireflies which can be observed in the evening. There's even a firefly cave under a small waterfall where you can see the fireflies very close. The hotel manager is very nice and polite, but the staff is not always working efficiently, though they tried hard. The check-in was very long and messy, there was some misunderstanding with deposits and client's credit cards, and not everyone of the staff understood English well enough. The suitcases were delivered to the rooms with big delays. The room was quite large and comfortable, and of course very clean. Almost all the rooms have garden views. There are L'Occitane amenities in the bathroom. Breakfasts were fine, but again - staff served everything very slowly, those who were in a hurry to the conference, needed to ask for the coffee several times. This hotel could be a nice conference venue, as it has a large business center and a lot of conference facilities, but they need serious modernization and design upgrade.

Massively luxurious hotel with beautifully manicured gardens and marble interior. I hope that gives you an idea of the height of class of the hotel!We arrived via taxi from the Mejiro station, just a 5 minute drive, probably the best option with our large luggage. Easy to get a taxi outside the station. The rest of the time we walked to the Edogawabashi station to get around town with our Suica card! It is about a 8-10 minute walk from the hotel entrance, or through the gardens of the hotel. Not much difference. Wouldn't advise the garden path late at night though, it was rather dark. Also the hotel garden gate closes at about 9pm I think. Well, no doubt the hotel is beautiful with lots of greenery. Many many Japanese couples have their wedding there, so beware during the weekends, you will probably bump into at least 2-3 wedding celebrations! Interesting to see, but I wouldn't have wanted to disturb them. Hint: don't walk through the gardens to get out on the weekends, you'd be intruding into crowds of wedding guests and photographers, at least during wedding season. The hotel is very clean and the rooms large and spacious. We didn't take breakfast there, but had dinner at the soba restaurant which was very pretty and tasty. Walking through the hotel and grounds transports you back to traditional Japan which is beautiful and luxurious, but almost uncomfortable for us, we (or at least I) felt that I was destroying the ambience of the hotel just by being there! Most of the people in the hotel were also dressed to the nines (for real). However, all the staff were very polite and kind, lending us umbrellas for rainy days and pointing us in the right direction for the trains, although I'm not sure how many hotel guests actually used the trains instead of taxis. The staff also speak English perfectly, so not to worry about language. Make sure you grab a map of the grounds and spend a few minutes walking through the hotel gardens with a camera! If you want an experience of Ultimate Japanese Luxury, in my opinion, this is the place to stay! This hotel has a shared shuttle to the airport and quite a cheap rate, and the bus is big and spacious. In typical Japanese timeliness, they overestimate the journey time by quite a bit, so you will most definitely be on time to catch your flight! We used the shuttle from the hotel to the airport, as we were arriving from Kanazawa.

Located in a beautiful and peaceful residential area away from shopping district and tourists. The scenic garden attached to the hotel is an attraction itself. Plus, there are nice restaurants hidden in the garden that are worth trying. At night, walk to the red bridge in the garden you will see hundreds of fireflies lit up in the dark brook valley, which reminds me of childhood. Hotel spa has natural spring and outdoor hot spring. Wish we had more time to spend in the outdoor hot spring. Pure relaxation! Service was excellent and our room was upgraded to the garden view. We spent three nights here and did not want to leave. Next time I will come back for one-week stay!

I have been to this hotel since 2002 when it was managed by Four Seasons. The service of reception has deteriorated a lot. The young receptionist did not check our passports and kept saying that the booking was for one room instead of two rooms. He did not listen to me and asked me to sign a check-in form with an Indian name on it. I told him that the form was not for me. He realised his mistakes. The first thing for a hotel receptionist is to identify the guest and the guy obviously skipped the process. The worst thing was that we could not get any lunch at the hotel which has nine restaurants. Why ? All the restaurants were fully booked by non-hotel guests. The restaurant receptionists simply told us to go away instead of offering waiting lists. The guest rooms are very nice as usual and the pool is absolutely fantastic. The restaurants serve very good food for reasonable prices. Hopefully, the hotel management can address the service issues.

This hotel was a former Four Seasons and we have stayed at a lot of Four Seasons. Every detail is exactly as if you were at a Four Seasons without Four Seasons prices. The room was impeccably clean and appointed. An amazing and large bathroom. The customer service is superb and every request is responded to quickly. Nightly turndown service is a nice touch and the gardens are so peaceful and beautiful. The gardens are a tourist spot but there are not a lot of crowds. It is so nice to wake up to those gardens in the morning. A nice location but there are not really any restaurant options outside of the hotel and hotel restaurants are a bit posh and expensive but that is the only distraction I can highlight. We will definitely stay here again.

This was our first time at the Chinzanso, and we adored it. Its a more classic looking hotel with old world charm, beautiful art, tapestry style curtains and antique style furnishings. The staff were attentive, thorough, and excellent. Great food, beautiful views of the city from our room, and overall an excellent experience. The gardens are not to be missed. This is more of a residential neighbourhood and is quieter than other tourist mainstays, like Shinjuku or Shibuya.Note: Do not dress sloppily, as even the guests at Chinzanso look respectable to match the environment. Also to be noted, the nearest train station is about ten minutes walk away. Its highly recommended that if you cannot read the station names, you purchase a JR Rail Pass some weeks before travelling to make your experience smooth (but only if you plan to use the train extensively, otherwise it is not worth it).

This hotel is simply spectacular. We went there for our honeymoon and we were amazed by the great service, amazing room, beautiful gardens this hotel offers. The restaurants are also amazing(we tried all of themDuring our stay and it was just too good).

An oasis in Tokyo. Rooms a large and airy. The garden is beautiful and it adds to stay to take a strawl in the garden after a hectic day in Tokyo. Then there is the superb staff and great service too! I would like to mention the Mr Sol, director of guest service, who was very helpful all the time and secured us a dinner booking on our last night in Tokyo. Chinzanso Hotel is all in all a great place to stay...and I didn't even mention the spa area!

Was back in Tokyo recently for business and had the pleasure of again staying here. Staff remember your name, the accommodation hits the mark with good size rooms, and request a garden view option offering a lovely start to the day. 5 minute taxi or 8 minute bus to the Yamanote JR line or short enjoyable stroll along the river to the Yurakucho subway line. Take in the afternoon tea if time permits. Many international hotel options in Tokyo, however this is one for those that have time to enjoy the hotel and is offerings. The spa and pool area have natural onsen water shipped in each week. Miyuki restaurant has offers fun teppanyaki spot and then take in the Yamachan restaurant in the neighborhood one night for dinner. In June they have the hotaru "firefly" and the autumn colours are very special later in the year. Look forward to my next return.

As others have indicated, this is one of the finest hotels you will ever stay in. Since other reviewers have done a fantastic job of extolling the hotel's many excellent features, I will concentrate on the extremely slow check-in. The check-in desk is small, only two men working when my associate and I checked in around 6 p.m. You take a seat and wait for them to call your name. After completing the registration process, you then take a seat again and wait for the bellhop to come and load your luggage. Once arriving in your room, you wait again for the bellhop to deliver your luggage.I had a similar experience at check-out. The clerk asked me to pay my mini-bar bill of 480 yen ($4.30) for a Coke, but I explained that I had left the money in the room. They had to verify that I had done this, which took quite a while. The report came back that I had left only 475 yen and that I owed 5 yen (approximately 4 cents). I didn't have any yen on me and had to hunt down my colleague for a coin. This whole episode delayed our departure 15 minutes, and it was all over 4 cents. But would I stay here again? Absolutely! The garden alone is worth a return trip.

I suppose this is easily the most luxurious property I have stayed at. Very luxurious rooms ( 450 sq feet plus) very large and beautiful property including a large beautiful garden, temple and a lake. Service Is top class. As you know the Japanese are amongst 'the most courteous' people in the world- service lives up your expectations. Go for morning jog / walk in the outdoors take a hot spring followed by a spa and in the evening relish the famed Yamazaki. All within the hotel premises !

I've stayed in a fair number of 5 star hotels in the last few years and have been completely floored by how amazing some of them can be. This one beats them all.We were upgraded to the executive suite which included a separate kitchen, large living room and dining room as well as the extensive bedroom suite. Our room looked over the Chinzanso garden; an amazing view at any time of day. But the service at this hotel is what made the experience. I never waited for anything, was surprised by the depth and friendliness of staff's service (especially for my son), and the concierge staff went out of their way to make our stay amazing.

The Chinzanso was the best or equal best hotel we have ever stayed in. In our experience, up there with the Luxembourg Parc in Paris and the Hotel Eden in Spietz. Indeed, we liked it so much that after spending 4 cays on arrival in Tokyo, we changed our booking to spend the final 3 days there as well.The rooms are spacious but useably so and the furnishings are quality (especially the bed!) The public spaces are also great and the hotel has a fabulous garden with its own Pagoda. Yes, it is nice to have a room overlooking the garden, but you pay for it - around 5000 yen a night. The rooms on the other side are just zs good and the view of Tokyo is fine.The public spaces are also excellent. We sampled the Japanese - both casual and kaiseki - and set menu Italian. All excellent.The service is excellent with good English. Guest relations are headed by Andre Sol who is Dutch and was very, very helpful and generous.Some tourist might find it a bit out of the way - it's a bit hike to the nearest subway. But it's not the far from Shinjuku and Ikebukuro We also fund (by walking) the pleasant restaurant and shopping precinct of Kagurazaka - stuffed with cost places to eat!Previously we have stayed at the Hotel Capitol. I would also recommend it without qualification, as true five=start quality and service., but in future we will stay at Chinsanzo.

My family and I typically fly standby so I had about 30 minutes before boarding the plane to book a hotel in Tokyo beginning the next night for 3 nights. I booked for 2 guests via Priceline since I was unable to specify that we needed a room for 3 adults including my wife and adult daughter (I've since discovered that it can be a big issue in Japan to arrive with an extra person). Not only did the Hotel Chinzanso reception desk work with us to upgrade to a suite for a reasonable fee, the entire staff did their utmost to ensure we were satisfied with our accommodations and our stay. We have to agree with another reviewer that the staff are some of the most gracious and hospitable of any hotel we have stayed in worldwide.Also, after now spending some time in vibrant Tokyo, I can appreciate the peaceful serenity and roominess of both the hotel and the beautiful adjacent park. Understandably weddings are popular here in springtime, and even the large wedding event during our Saturday departure was held with much grace and beauty. I can't say enough good things about our short stay at the Hotel Chinzanso Tokyo. Kudos to Matsu the chief concierge for helping us with additional reservations at our next stop in Japan, Kanazawa. Kudos to all the staff truly.Also, if you have the opportunity to stay in a room with access to the executive "Water Lounge" don't miss it -- it's a fantastic way to rehydrate! It's one-of-a-kind!

This is actually the first review that I'm writing, but there is a reason for that. And the reason is that this was by far the best hotel experience that I have had. We (2 adults, 2 kids) spent 6 nights in Chinzanso in our two week holiday in Japan. We had the standard room with cityview. Room was large enough for our family and the view was stunning especially at nights. The bathroom was spacious and the separate bath and shower closet is always a big plus and a minimun that good hotel should have. Btw the shower closet was large enough for two adults (good for parents having their kids in the same hotelroom) The nearest stations were Mejiro (JR, very good one for Japan rail pass owners) and Edogawabashi (sub). They are not quite close but the taxi to Mejiro cost about 900 yenis, so about 9 euros. Of course you can also use the bus which stop is next to hotel. At evenings, the kids were quite tired for travelling around Tokyo so we tried also the restaurants in Chinzanso. We had dinners in japanese style restaurants Mucha-an, Mokushundo and Miyuki because we wanted to eat japanese food. Restaurants in hotels are sometimes a risk (except Michelin star restaurants in some hotels), but this time there were no risk at all. We all liked the food in all of those restaurants very much. The experience of authenticity was actually better than most of the restaurants that we had dinners in our travel.We tried also the Afternoon Tea set in Le Jardin. No complaints. And I have to mention the Chinzansos garden which is extraordinary and special for the hotel in the middle of Tokyo. I have spent many nights in 5-star hotels around the Europe and USA. Not until now I know what excellent service is. The hotel staff did everything right and even exceeded the high expectations that I already had. I believe that Chinzanso is one of the best hotels in Tokyo. We will definitely go there again.

What can you say about Hotel Chinzanso, this is one of the most stunning places I've stayed at, the staff are all so friendly and helpful, the hotel and the grounds are heavenly, our room is stunning, you could not ask for more, tomorrow or the next day we will check out the pool which is also grand, definitely if you are in Tokyo this is the perfect place to stay

I understand this is the former Four Seasons hotel and its absolutely spectacular. I travel fairly regularly for business or pleasure and this one of the best hotels I've stayed in. We took the airport bus to this hotel and its the last stop taking about two hours from Narita. The hotel is very plush but it never overwhelmes the guest. All service staff are unfailingly polite and helpful and the service levels are probably the best that I've ever experienced. The hotel is a couple of hundred metres uphill from the Edogawabashi station and it was pleasant to walk up and down the hill in March. The concierge staff speak excellent English (very helpful for the non-Japanese). We took advantage of the luggage transfer service to our next hotel in Kyoto and concierge staff took care of it in a jiffy.F&B quality is very good. The hotel bar is very nice though we would recommend avoiding the finger food and stick to the drinks. The bar has a very good selection of whiskeys. We would also recommend the Sakura flavoured drinks in Cherry Blossom season. We ate in the Japanese restaurant and the food with sake pairing was excellent. Service staff were a bit harried as the restaurant was quite full but we didn't experience inordinate delays. The breakfast service is the only let-down in this hotel. There are two breakfast options. A set menu in the restaurant or a traditional buffet breakfast in the lobby. The buffet has rather limited choice without a live egg-station. This is something that the hotel management needs to look into.The loveliest part of this hotel has to be the garden. We specifically asked for a garden view room after reading the other reviews and it is a sight to behold. We went in spring and the spring colours were just coming out in their full glory. The silence in the garden is something to be experienced. The harmony of water, plants and structures in the garden is very soothing. We spent a couple of hours in the garden just soaking it all in. We would come back to this hotel just to be able to experience the garden.

review_body: Excellent spa hotel within a big japanese garden, we stayed with our 4 kids and all of them loved it, super friendly staff, several restaurant options, only minus from potential extra charges on breakfast

This is third time I stay in this spectacular hotel. It gets better every time. Only a great hotel will satisfy my traveling habits. I normally leave the hotel daily in the afternoon. Hotel for me is not just breakfast and bed. For me quality of the hotel matters a lot because I do spend good time in the hotel. Hotel Chinzanso is a perfect choice for me. Apart from facilities provided, the spacious Japanese Garden is spectacular and make your stay beautiful. Its an experience to have breakfast while looking down on to the garden. The two beautiful churches on the corner of the garden holding several weddings ceremonies during the weekends are music to my proud Muslim ears. The cherry trees and people walking along the water channel just behind the hotel make you self-sufficient and very comfortable being at the hotel. a Lovely stretch form my morning walks. I never return back to my room before passing by shops to buy my daily share of fresh fruits. I love Japan and specially Tokyo. Chinzanso is home to me. Looking forward to spring 2018. Thanks to my Chinzanso family.

Hotel Chinzanso is amazing. The garden is beautiful, the rooms are spacious and the service is excellent. I could not fault anything. It really was perfect. I loved the Yu spa, especially the hot spring bath. Room service was excellent and housekeeping did an excellent job everyday. I can't wait to return.

We visited Hotel Chinzanso for the cherry blossom lunch buffet as well as a quick tour around the hotel and gardens. The mix of Japanese and western dishes at the buffet were creative and of top quality, we especially loved the steak with onion rings and the scallops with a green cream sauce. The chocolate opera indeed melted in the mouth as advertised. The walk around the garden revealed the early-blooming cherry blossoms and a view of the Japanese garden from the top is always breathtaking. An amazing hotel with impeccable service and food. We'll be back in the middle of cherry blossom season too!

Stayed there 2 nights for a business trip and was amazed by the place. Beautiful surroundings, old school proper 5 star hotel and amazing staff. The hotel and grounds are super well maintained and the onset facilities are great! stay there, you won't be disappointed.

I am currently staying at hotel Chinzanso in Tokyo and I am absolutely amazed about the hospitality and attention to details there. The rooms are beautiful, the staff is well trained and super friendly and André the Manager provides an incredible level of oversight and guidance. He clearly knows what good looks like which is not easy to find in Tokyo. I have been to many fancy hotels in Tokyo over the past 15 years but I would declare Hotel Chinzanso my new clear favorite hotel.

We travel as a family fairly often and had a pleasure to stay in Hotel Chinzanso as a family of 5 with 2 kids (7 and 8 yrs) for 6 nights. Pure pleasure on all levels. Location is not central but allows you to experience a feeing of "real people" Tokyo. Wonderfully kept gardens, friendly staff and beautiful property.Highly recommended.

A highly underrated top notch 5 star hotel very much in the Japanese mold . As the ex-Four Seasons Hotel in Tokyo, you will not miss the trappings of a neo classic Four Season. It is maintains the charm but is run by the likes of Japanese efficiency that is 2nd to none. Outstanding service from an attentive and professional team. Only down side is the location is a little out of the way from the usual hustle and bustle of Tokyo tourist belt. Not a problem is you drive and park in the hotel ample parking lost. Great Japanese restaurants. Amazing firefliy japanese garden that must be enjoyed at least once . Quite a famous local attraction for viewing fireflies at night with the locals! All in all a great hotel and a huge secret that eludes most travelers to Tokyo looking to stay at a 5 star hotel.

Located in a quiet neighborhood in Tokyo, Hotel Chinzanso is definitely one of the finest five-star hotels we have stayed in as a family. I had very high expectations after all the glowing reviews, and this hotel did not disappoint. We were thoroughly impressed about absolutely everything! Prior to Arrival:Their highly efficient concierge team arranged for our round trip airport transfer, and secured a dinner reservation at Mokushundo. They replied to all my e-mails very promptly. Everything went smoothly, even with our 2-hr flight delay.Arrival:We arrived after 9pm. Hotel driveway entrance is brightly lit up, and the beautiful lobby is tastefully decorated for Christmas. Excellent guest services all-around. Reception was very warm and welcoming, and we had 2 bellhops for luggage assistance.Six-night stay:My family of 4 (hubby and 2 girls, ages 12 and 6), stayed for 6 nights, so we were able to avail of their extended stay rate. We were given a renovated room on the 11th floor in the Hotel wing, with an amazing city view. It was very beautiful and spacious, with a gorgeous bathroom that boasted a separate bathtub and shower, toilet, and L'Occitane products throughout.They don't make you wait here. Housekeeping was very speedy with special requests... and our room was always spotless. Room service, which we used 3x for breakfast, is quite impressive. They are thorough, and fast. We also had a very pleasant experience at Miyuki, where we had breakfast 2x. Their concierge team is the best. They're on top of everything. There is a meticulous attention to detail. Amazing.The extensive spa facilities are free for 2 persons per day, and I was able to enjoy this with my 6-yr old daughter. The pool is warm, and massive...and we enjoyed everything, especially the jaccuzzi. Consistently excellent service, wherever we went.Getting AroundSo many options. We were on buses (bus stop is in front of the Tower wing), and we used all train stations in the area. Tokyo's transportation system is highly reliable --- all you need is a pasmo or suica card, and the right app to figure out your route to get around. You can use cash at the bus, too, if your card runs out of charge. We only used the taxi on our last day, when we were in a hurry to go to Sunshine City (2 miles away) for last minute shopping, and lunch. Hotel GroundsBreathtaking. I almost cried at the sight of the garden. You just have to see for yourself.DepartureAirport limousine bus was on time, and luggage assistance staff were so efficient. The drive was very pleasant, with no problems. Arrived at the airport 20 mins earlier than scheduled, which was great, as Narita has so many shops! In ConclusionWe did not want to leave. Tokyo is a beautiful city, which offers a feast for the senses. This hotel is an oasis of serenity. World-class service. 5-stars all the way. This was our first time in Tokyo, and I hope it won't be the last. We will definitely stay at Hotel Chinzanso Tokyo again. To the entire staff of Hotel Chinzanso Tokyo, arigatou gozaimasu.

Exceptionally clean rooms, Amazing view of the garden and and extra amazing garden with waterfall, streams and little bridges.Huge property and very helpful staff. Nespresso machine in every roomIn a more quite part of Tokyo and the property has many amazing restaurants but must book in advance.The value was great since we found it online on sale

Beautiful hotel with big size rooms and everything you need for a comfortable stay including 5 restaurants on site with exquisite menus. It is located a bit away from touristy spots but train is close and easy to use to access these. Local eateries are a bit iffy but then again we didn't look too hard. Mostly ate in hotels restaurants. Five star all the way.

This luxurious hotel has a fantastic zen garden with a pavillion, a lake and a stream. Great place for an evening meditation. The rooms are nice and spacious, the night view is amazing from the rooms. The subway is 10 minutes walking distance.

Stayed here only 1 night and was with a group that arrived around 7 pm for dinner in their La Jardin banquet room. Food was decent, but portions small. Banquet employees were very nice. We were given a room on the 14th floor and upon entering the room, noticed a strong smoke smell. Also, room did not have outlets by the beds to plug our electronics in. When looking under the nightstand, I noticed a lot of messy wiring. Behind our bed, noticed wallpaper peeling off. The room decor is more traditional than updated. They have a automatic panel by the beds that allows you to close the lights and window curtains with a push of a button. The marble bathroom was very large and had a large tub and separate shower stall, but there are signs of mold forming between the tiles. The toilet is also in a small separate room and automatically warms the seat upon sitting. Amenities provided include a hairdryer, toothbrush, toothpaste, hairbrush, but no iron or ironing board. Overall, very nice hotel but could use some improvements here in there.

I am staying at the Chinzanso Tokyo as I write this and I have to say this is by far the best service and most attentive staff I have ever encountered in any of my travels. I have stayed in more luxurious rooms but the room I received is very spacious, extremely comfortable and has a phenomenal shower and bath.One added luxury is that the hotel has L'Occitan toiletries - which have always been my favorite. And they leave delicious pastries, chocolate and free bottles of water every day. I know we sometimes takes those things for granted but I've stayed at hotels in the U.S. that charged nearly $1,000 a night and still charge for the water and wifi.I highly recommend this hotel.

My family of 4 stayed for 6 nights in August 2016. We had a great time. It’s a proper 5 star hotel with all the facilities (superb pools and gym, absolutely exceptional concierge services even by Japanese standards which are normally excellent, perfect room service, our room was beautiful etc). There’s a really beautiful garden with a temple so try to get a garden view room. The location isn’t central but there’s a metro nearby and Japanese taxis are reasonably priced and highly available. I would have to say that the food which is proficient and wonderfully served is … well, a touch overpriced at times, even by Tokyo standards. C’est la vie – it was an enjoyable experience

This was our second hotel in Tokyo and wish we stayed here the whole time! Building is gorgeous, it is old with a character yet extremely well maintained. There is a big garden and if you are staying at a room with a garden view, a delight to wake up to. Amazing spa facilities with a hot spring outside among trees! Many restaurants to choose from whether it be European or Japanese. I strongly recommend the breakfast at Il Teatro...And the staff... The nicest and kindest people you can meet. They bend backwards to make sure everything is perfect with a genuine smile on their faces. I care about the places I stay and Chinzanso definitely made it to my top three! I cannot recommend this place highly enough. Thank you Chinzanso Hotel!!!

From the moment we arrived, the service was the finest we experienced in Japan. The gardens are lush and beautiful, the concierges helpful and know the answers to all questions, sweet gestures like giving us a card (with the name of the hotel) and bottled water when we got in the taxi to the beautiful room with an exquisite view. And the only place that had fresh decaf coffee! Not to mention the sublime restaurants.

review_body: My Japanese friends took me to Hotel Chinzaso, Tokyo for lunch. The food at Miyuki is very good and the price is also very reasonable. To my surprise the hotel is beautiful, after lunch we walked around the Garden. The surroundings of the hotel is pretty and quiet.Will try to stay here next time we come to Tokyo.Just a reminder the location of Hotel Chinzaso is not so convenient.

There is nothing to dislike about Chinzanso. I have the habit of trying a couple of hotels in the cities I visit and this time I deeply regret it. I stayed in pretty miserable and overpriced joints this time. Not Chinzanso, it was by far the best and I'd even go as far as to say fairly priced. They have a great concierge thatWill organize and help you on anything. The gardens are gorgeous and worth themselves a visit. The spa/gym is (surprise , for Japan ) included and has (another surprise) great opening hours (gym 24h). The gym is well equipped if you like free weights and also have a lot of stuff for Pilates. The rooms are spotless beautiful and spacious. The bathroom is another high-light, huge, with all the amenities. The beds make you feel as would you have slept in heaven. It is far from the train station, but just get a can for about 1000¥ and you'll be fine. I'd stay again, by the same fare. Better said, I'll stay again.

This is a truly unique hotel in Tokyo, where most luxury hotels are skyscrapers, Chinzano stands out with its homely comforting feeling and beautiful garden, a true rarity in a city where space is precious. From the moment of arrival the staff are unfailingly polite and helpful in true Japanese fashion. The multi course dinner cooked on volcanice stones from Mount Fuji at the Japanese restaurant Mokushundo is a MUST try, as the love and care they take to prepare the food is so gentle it can only be described as an art form. The garden is a joy to wander through with a 1500 year old Pagoda in it and we were lucky enough to spot fireflies at certain times of the year. While it is not as centrally located as many other hotels, I always find myself coming back to Chinzanso for that special feeling of being home away from home.

We were travelling with our 2 kids in Tokyo for the first time. While planning, we were so keen on finding a hotel with rooms bigger than Tokyo standard, one that could accommodate us and our luggage...So glad we found Hotel Chinzanso. Our room was very spacious. The property is big, oozing with traditional sophistication, and surrounded by their very own sprawling Japanese garden (which we imagined to be really breathtaking in autumn). It's a bit isolated but there's a bus stop right in front of the hotel. JR Mejiro Station is just a short ride via Bus 61. Edogawabashi is also only 10 minutes away by foot via the gardens gate/riverside.The staff were very polite and attentive. We availed of their complimentary luggage storage service when we traveled to Hakone. When we came back, our baggage were already waiting for us in our room. Chocolates were also given daily as part of their turn down service. My son accidentally broke one of the glasses in the bathroom while brushing, I was expecting we'd be charged for it but was very delighted to find out it wasn't included in our bill.After a quick check-out process, we took the Limousine Bus from the hotel to Narita Airport—very convenient!

It was a pleasant stay at hotel chinzanso Tokyo. The Japanese breakfast and buffet breakfast was good. The garden within the hotel is very pretty. The rooms are also very spacious and clean. Restaurants and convenience stores is about a 10 min walk away.

The quiet Japanese restaurant is located at the far end of a long walking path set in a lush garden setting next to the Hotel Chinzanso Tokyo. The restaurant features multi-course meals (kaiseki) cooked on hot stones; the menu selection is varied and starts at 5500 yen (excluding taxes), which is an excellent value for Tokyo. The manager and staff are most helpful. Allow some extra time to walk through the extensive gardens before or after your meal -- it's a popular venue for upscale Japanese weddings. When I visited, there were several brides dressed in traditional kimonos and others in western bridal wear.

Incredible service from the Concierge, was able to book at short notice and have a car pickup organized while in transit via Heathrow. Enjoyed an upgrade to a garden view room and a few days of quiet in such a hectic city. My friend came to visit from Shibuya and said (as a local) that she had never had a chance to visit but would easily come again as the garden was so beautiful. Really enjoyed wandering the neighbourhood, and took the hotel's transport to my next destination. Would love to come back and stay a month and enjoy it again.

We stayed in a Western Premier King Room for a night just because we wanted to have a five star experience during our stay. A seasoned five star guest will no doubt have some gripes because when you are at this level minor things can create a stiff black mark, but for me, I was more than impressed by the service and attentiveness of staff. I usually go for four star design hotels with sprinkles of five-star, so Chinzanso was a little different to what I typically sign up for. What attracted me were the grounds and garden which are truly a reason to stay in itself as well as the pool and spa area. And just staying somewhere that's so overtly opulent with such a cultural feel as an experience. The hotel itself looks opulent - it's grand with marble and long staircases. It really is quite a beautiful setting. The room was large, even by western standards and the bathroom was probably one of the best I've ever stayed in and comparable to upper end Vegas hotels in terms of space and functionality. Separated shower, separated toilet, bath and enormous vanity with it's own TV. We likely got this hotel on a cheap rate because everything was extra. I didn't think I should have to spend another 4000 odd yen to access the Yu Spa, but spas are my thing so I did it and it was worth it, but again, once you're in there food and drinks are another extra on top. I'm not entirely certain but I think that the spa fee covers you for two days. Pool area is fantastic, has a large spa, steam room, dry room and a hot spring. I definitely felt relaxed. We went in firefly season and they cultivate them for this which can be viewed on the bridge of the garden. I had no idea what fireflies looked like and was expecting a light show going off the promotion. They are small, slow moving bugs that light up beautifully as they fly, but there aren't heaps of them - maybe ten - which is probably normal. The concierge was great and helped me with whatever I needed quickly and easily. Staff saw us right into our room and helped us with our luggage and any questions we had about the grounds. All in all Chinzanso left an indelible memory for me having stayed there and for that I would rate it highly.

Great upscale rooms and service in what presents as a high quality five star hotel. But there are several glaring, to my mind, exceptions. First, the location, while probably fine for business stays, is terrible for tourists and travelers. A taxi or bus to a nearby train station and then often a train line transfer is necessary to get most anywhere touristically interesting. It's just so far from any tourist sight.Second, the restaurant food is significantly below standard. The three lobby floor restaurants have sparse menus and even though they say they are Italian or whatever...the food is with a Japanese twist. This was not acceptable to this reviewer. Plus it is extremely expensive. ¥1800, about $17, for a regular glass of beer is ridiculous. Not everyone is on expense account. My ¥3410 ($31) breakfast brought juice, coffee and three breads, ok so far. But the two scrambled eggs were significantly undercooked and watery. The two slices of bacon were incinerated and basically inedible. Reporting of displeasure (and a firm suggestion the executive chef go into the kitchen and check the abilities of the line cooks) was met with a shrug and not even an apology.A chicken Caesar salad (around $20+) was dry, with poorly cut lettuce, excessive parmesan slices and chicken which was dry and appeared to be sliced off a processed roll, like lunch meat often used for sandwiches. It was certainly not worth the price but moreover, it was completely at odds with the quality image of this hotel. With under two dozen items on the whole menu, they should be able to make a salad right.The worst sin, however, is they serve shark's fin in at least one of the restaurants. This should lower my rating even further but I'm feeling benevolent at the moment.With all the fine hotels in Tokyo, one shouldn't have to be confined in isolation with limited food choices.

I spent 7 nights at Chinzanso on a half holiday/ half work trip. The booking was organised through my work and I was not hugely keen on this hotel because of its location and how it looked on their website - I am more of a fan of modern hotels, not traditional, lavish looking hotels. BUT I was pleasantly surprised by this hotel! Firstly, the service was impeccable. The conceirge staff went out of their way to ensure I could get to where I needed to go. On one day in particular, they had ordered a taxi to take me to the office. But it was taking too long so I went to jump into a random taxi as it pulled up. Before I could even shut the taxi door, staff had printed out directions to the office and handed it to the taxi driving informing him of where I needed to go. They gave me a bottle of water because it was a hot day too!I stayed in a superior king room which was exceptionally spacious for a "standard" room. The bathroom was very spacious and nice too. I didn't eat often in the hotel restaurants, but for the few nights that I did the food was very good. The location turned out to be ok as it was not far from the office, but sometimes challenging to get to other destinations if I was going to travel by train (I had not been to Japan before, so the whole train thing was a little confusing). There is a local subway (Edogawabashi) around a 7 minute walk from the hotel which was handy. There are a few shops and things around there, but not much. The nearest shopping & restaurant centre I found on the subway line was Sunshine City/ Ikebukudo, which is only 2 stops away. The Chinzanso gardens are nice but not particularly big. You can spend maybe 30 minutes in there and see everything. The Mokushundo restaurant (old-style dishes cooked on hot lava rocks) in the garden looked amazing but unfortunately I was not able to dine there. I am torn between giving this hotel a 4 to 5 star review. It's really only the location that brings it down a little bit for me. But if the location suits you, then it really is a fabulous choice.

We stayed at this hotel for a week. The service was impeccable, in particular from housekeeping, room service and at the fitness center. There's a beautiful garden, well worth visiting several times. We will keep a great memory of our stay.

We recently spent three days at the Chinzanso and can't say enough about the service. From Andre Sol's tour of the extensive gardens to Mr. Kondo's assistance in all matters from transportation and restaurant reservations to assisting our friends we couldn't have had a better experience.

This hotel has unrivaled grounds inside Tokyo. The size of the garden is unrivaled with a huge Pogoda fish pond and garden. This was one of the main draws of why we booked this hotel, its around 10 minutes walk from the nearest metro station so ideally situated to get you in and around Tokyo but leaving the hustle and bustle of the city behind (Trust me you will want the quite!) The decor and style of this hotel is very classic the fixtures and fittings in the room could do with an update, the curtains and beds look old as well as the bathrooms. Having said that it adds character to hotel the amazing amenities more than make up for the older furniture they really have supplied every amenity you could ever want in the room, too many to list!The staff are impeccable extremely helpful absolutely professional and always find time to help you. For the first time in years we experienced a real concierge service who provided insightful useful information as well as booking various experiences we requested. If you want an authentic hotel with a classic feel outside of the extremely busy city center then this should be your choice.

review_body: A beautiful hotel in an old samurai garden in the heart of Tokyo. The hotel itself is new but exudes the comfort and luxury of a French country chateau. The gardens are a treat - old buddhas and buildings have been moved from other parts of Japan to join the the cherry, plum and maple trees that date back to the 14th century. This is the place to relax by the sound of a Japanese waterfall and recuperate after a busy day's work or sight-seeing in the capital.

Very good staff, polite, professional, speaking more than correct English.Our room was upgraded to a deluxe corner garden view and was quiet large for a room in Tokyo. Nice surprise for the upgrade also.Choice of American and Japanese breakfast, i tried both, i preferred the Japanese one.Location is not prime but still good. Garden is amazingNice choice of restaurants, grill, soba,Italian, afternoon tea....etc

Staying at the Hotel Chinzanso was a highlight of my visit to Tokyo! The gardens and outdoor jacuzzi were the main reason I would recommend it. I would suggest allowing at least one entire day just to stay at the hotel, walk through the gardens and enjoy the facilities. It would be a shame to stay at Chinzanso and not have enough time to appreciate it's beautiful grounds! It really feels a world away from the hustle and bustle of the city. Our twin room was comfortable and very spacious, much bigger than most hotel rooms in Japan. The decor in my room was antique, french provincial inspired, but it did feel a little dated, especially the floral curtains. The bathroom was large, with a big bath and shower, lots of marble and really great amenities. The L’Occitane toiletries were a nice touch. The gardens are the star of the Chinzanso! They are enormous and there are many different areas, with bridges, ponds, fish, a pagoda, a shrine, gorgeous ancient stone statues, and endless varieties of trees and flowers including some beautiful cherry blossoms and maples. It’s a garden lovers paradise! And it’s incredibly photogenic, I couldn’t help but think it would be the most picturesque hotel in Tokyo for a wedding!The indoor swimming pool is large and naturally lit which is nice. The gym was decent sized and well equipped. The best facility by far though, was the outdoor jacuzzi. It’s a stunning shallow hot pool built in natural stone surrounded by weeping maple trees! It’s the most picture perfect little spa I’ve ever seen, especially on a cold day when you can see the steam floating above the water. I would return to the Chinzanso just to spend another hour in that jacuzzi!I didn’t eat at the restaurants, however the a la carte breakfast which was included in my room was very good. It was in a nice little breakfast room with fresh flowers and it felt very upmarket. I had the American breakfast with coffee and juice and it was tasty and served quickly. Overall, my stay at the Chinzanso was enjoyable. I wasn’t blown away by the room, but the service was pleasant and the gardens were stunning. I would recommend it to anyone who likes the outdoors and appreciates horticulture. The Hotel Chinzanso is centrally located, but if you are arriving with luggage, you must take a taxi as it’s too far to walk to the train station.

I spent four nights at this gem and I loved every piece of it. The staff we super friendly. Very professional. The hotel is one of the most, if not the most, elegant I have ever been. The garden is amazing and if you are there around sakura you are a lucky man. The lounge in the 12 floor is also a hidden gem. I like it because I can have my espresso there. I was however disappointed by the restaurant in the 2 floor who did not have spot for me for breakfast and they did not specify if I will ever get a spot. If you have enough budget you need to book a garden view. It is amazing. If I come back to Tokyo I will definitely visit this palace in the heart of Tokyo. And they have a nice gym. Small but it has all what we need.

We began our trip to Japan in Tokyo and although there were many hotels to choose from we selected Hotel Chinzanso. We were overwhelmed by the warm and gracious greeting we received by staff members waiting outside as we arrived. The hotel itself is beautiful and the surrounding gardens are exquisite especially since the cherry blossoms were in bloom. This was our reason for staying here rather than staying in the busiest part of the city. We were escorted to our suite which had the most fabulous view of the gardens, we didn't want to leave. In the evenings we enjoyed having cocktails in the bar. One night we enjoyed dinner at Miyuki and two in the Bistro. The service was excellent throughout the hotel and the food outstanding. We must mention that the pool and spa area was wonderful and greatly appreciated after our long flight. Everyone should experience the Chinzanso, it stands out, above all other hotels. Thanks to the entire staff for making our stay so memorable.Molly and Charles

Beautiful garden, attentive customer service, wonderful food don't miss the Japanese breakfast, I have been here a couple of times and always enjoyed my stays. It is a bit further away from most things but definitely worth that extra effort.

Unless you are glutton for business district high-rises, this serene former Four Seasons is definitely worth the stay in Tokyo, notwithstanding its 10 minute walk to a metro stop or slightly off city-center location. But what it lacks perhaps in being in the middle of everything is a relaxing, luxurious, green ambience that makes for a very very comfortable stay after Tokyo's bustle and hustle. The staff is unbelievably friendly and efficient, the rooms very very comfortable, the garden views peaceful. The spa--heated and covered pool, jacuzzi, a hot springs--is very rejuvenating and the attached gardens are quite stunning. I would totally stay there again.
