review_body: I felt like royalty when I stayed here. This hotel, which used to be a Four Seasons until they decided to become independent, has a massive garden with its own centuries-old pagoda in the center. You can get lost for hours in that garden, or have a traditional tea ceremony in one of their tea houses within it (ask the concierge about that). The rooms were impeccable, with elegant furnishings and massive bathrooms, and the staff is as professional as you could possibly hope for. They even left a tray of expensive fruits in my room simply because they heard me say that I like fruit. Free of charge.My room had a view of the garden and the pagoda, as I believe most (if not all) rooms do. I would highly recommend this hotel in the spring to see the cherry blossoms!If there's a downside to this hotel, it's that it's a bit of a walk to the nearest train station (15+ minutes), but there is a nearby bus station and an army of taxis ready to take you wherever you want to go.

I took a business trip with 2 nights in this hotel. The meeting took place in the other wing of the hotel. Very convenient. Rooms were exceptionally tidy. Wifi was fast enough. Many restaurants but I did not manage to get a table where I wanted - should have pre-booked which sucks. Access with metro to city centre is not the most convenient one. Seems to be a popular venue for local weddings.

Easily one of the best places I have ever stayed. The staff were incredible, the room beautiful, gardens unbelievably beautiful, pool great, in a really nice residential neighbourhood so you get to see a slice of the real tokyo.

We stayed for 5 nights in January 2016. While there are plenty of luxury hotels in Tokyo, this one, for the exceptional beauty of its garden and the taste of its decor and facilities, must rank as one of the best. It's fundamentally a wedding venue (it started off that way in a previous and perhaps even ancient avatar) so expect every corner of every part to be photogenic, and service to be charming, discrete and polished to the highest degree with polyglot European as well as Japanese staff. It is in other words a pampering hotel - the kind that every evening hand writes the weather forecast for you and leaves chocolates after the turn-down service, and sometimes has a harpist or pianist in one of the public areas. If you treat it only as a business hoel (which we saw it was used as too) it's a waste. We used three of its restaurants and they ranged from the very good to the terrific - not cheap but not outrageous either. We also had martinis on the bar - they offer around 100 variations, including the "Camelia", which is laced with gold dust. We didn't use or even visit the spa facilities but I'm confident that if we had they would have been up to par with the rest. There is a charming lounge on the 12th floor with a great view of the gardens that guests can enjoy during the day. It has free coffee and tea (these are also provided in the very well appointed rooms - the hotel even has its own mineral water which provides freely for guests in the rooms). The one downside is that it is a little off the beaten track -the nearest underground is Edogawabashi, a relaxed 10 minute walk away through the gardens and along the cherry-tree lined canal path. It's 30 minutes walk through the back streets from the small but fabulous shopping and restaurant area of Kagurazaka. If you want a hotel that pampers and helps you to relax in the megalopolis, this is it. We'll certainly be back.

Yet another hotel that I would give four and a half stars to. Come on Tripadvisor, give us more flexibility!The Chinzanso is the height of restrained elegance. It is a reminder of the 'grand' hotels of the past, with a truly wonderful garden, and some very elegant dining options. Although well maintained, the hotel is starting (only just starting) to show signs of wear and tear. What it isn't, though, is up-to-the-minute. It doesn't have the wow factor of some more modern properties, but then I don't think it's aiming to. That isn't to say that it's old - the building is relatively new (I would guess built in the 80s) and very nice. But it is designed to be elegant (that word again), not modern.I think that the hotel could probably benefit from having at least one less formal eating/drinking option, even their "casual dining" is somewhat non-casual!If you're looking for the excitement, bustle and chaos that Tokyo can offer then this isn't for you. If you want to relax then maybe it is.Positives* Lovely rooms* Nice food (the restaurants in the garden especially so)* Quiet - almost an oasis of tranquility!* Free wifiNegatives* Wifi slightly patchy* Somewhat too restrained

We stayed at the Chinzanso hotel for a few days in late December 2015. It was an amazing experience, the service from all members of staff was just outstanding and very personal. Concierge service is particularly helpful and friendly. We mostly dealt with Serge who was a great guy. The hotel is a bit far away from main attractions, but if you don't mind that, it is a great place to stay. The garden view rooms are very lovely. Nothing seemed too much for them to assist with or organize. Slightly more expensive than others, but very much worth it.

Luxury great hotel with the stunning views over the city. Extensive gardens with old Japanese artifacts and beautiful old trees. Various restaurants to choose from including fantastic grill w kobe beef cooked over lava stone. Swimming pool in the basement. However long walk to metro or bus ride. For me it was not convenient as i needed easy access to public transport. But the overall experience was excellent

The hotel is clean and the service is nice. But is outdated, probably need a renovate. Plus it is in the middle of nowhere, need to take a 25-30 mins cab drive every day to get to the center of Tokyo. That's probably why the price is cheap. There are a lot of amenities in the hotel.

I always wanted to stay at this hotel since I saw it in the early 2000s, when it was Four Seasons Chinzanso. As I understand the Four Seasons franchise is gone, so now it is only Chinzanso. The hotel is very nice, but it has something old in it, I can't say what exactly, but it seems to be behind the curve. Compared to other luxury hotels it seems to me this hotel remains behind its peers. Now I don't want to be critical - the hotel was super-clean, the staff very friendly and helpful. But the room seemed to be the room of a luxury hotel from the 1970s. I don't know what exactly gave me that impression, the atmosphere, the lack of decorations maybe. And yes, management is getting sloppy a bit. On the desk there was a paper from management apologizing for some repairs which could make noise during the month of October. And I was staying there at the end of November:) Apart from these little points, what I did not like was the breakfast. The food quality was good, but the lady who would get my breakfast ticket and show me to my table had an unpleasant attitude - almost like a school staff taking pupils to the table. No welcoming, no smiles, no politeness, just down to business, made me feel like I was about to be fed. Plus I had to wait for a table to become available, for about 5 minutes. It's not long I know, but I just don't see a luxury hotel where you wait for your table at breakfast. This is a first timer for me to be honest. As a conclusion, I don't regret having stayed at the hotel, just because I was so curious in the past, but I would not go again.

This was a recommendation from a business partner and to be honest, it was a perfect choice. Huge rooms, friendly stuff. The hotel is just beside a wonderful peaceful park, what is not self effident in Tokyo.We came in from Haneda and used the limosine shuttle, no need to take a taxi. It is far more expansive but not really faster.

i went there for my friend's wedding so i haven't stayed. it's kinda far from the station. there is a big garden in the hotel, and it's beautiful.one thing that i want to say to this hotel's wedding meals. meals were always carried with "not hot". everything was a bit cold. it's good hotel but i was kinda dissapointed.

We knew this hotel was not down town Tokyo, but that was okay because we wanted it to use as a relaxing area after the 11h flight and a very busy period at work. It is located in a beautiful park. Staff was very helpful and talked good English, even the chambermaid. Service was excellent and everything was perfectly clean. Don't forget to use the spa in the Japanese garden. (Entry via the indoor pool.) Perfect wireless coverage.The only minus point was the breakfast. We booked a bed & breakfast package, so we expected that everything related to the breakfast was included. Wrong! You get a budget you can use to order a Japanese breakfast (it is the same everyday except the type of fish) or a few items at the American breakfast. If you want more, like a cup of coffee you have to pay extra. (Breakfast tastes and looks great, see the picture.) So the selection is very limited and if you want more than a basic fixed breakfast you have to pay. I didn't like that a bit. Feels like NYC-style daylight robbery.I can recommend this hotel: great service, high quality and spotless.

Classically beautiful Tokyo hotel set outside of the City's core. Right in the middle of a park. Stifling luxury with ornate marble and detailed wall paper, but in its kitschy way I like it. The Japanese style breakfast was perfect. The room's view was excellent. The concierge secured reservations at a wonderful Ginza restaurant with no problems for me. My travel agent secured me a very affordable rate.It was a bit of a walk from the metro station and I regret not taking a cab with my heavy bag. However, the walk after my long flight was probably good for me. I would absolutely book again on my next trip.

Historical Luxury hotel. My favorite Spa has outdoor Juccuzy in the garden. I felt so comfortable to look at the trees and waterfall. Indoor pool is not big, but very comfortable. Guests can't use Spa b/w 6pm -8pm, it was so stressful for me, because I wanted to swim before the dinner. 素晴らしい庭をもつ椿山荘。滞在中、スパで楽し寛いだ一時を過ごせたのですが、6pmから8pmまで、ゲストはプールや風呂、サウナかわ利用出来なくて困りました。又、ゲストでも4000¥程の利用料金が必要のには、驚きました。もっとグローバルなホテルかと想像してましたが、ドメスティックなシステムが残るホテルでした。

Let me say upfront that this is one of the most amazing hotels in the world capitals and I definitely recommend it for a stay in Tokyo. I suspect that after dropping the Four Seasons name a couple of years ago it might not be on the radar screen of many Westerns. Don't be fooled - this is a world class five star hotel and more, meeting and in some ways exceeding the 4S standards. This is a classic, a "grand dame of Tokyo".Two key factors: 1) Exceptional relentless focus on customer service and satisfaction even by Japanese standards; 2) Tranquility and beauty of the setting. 3) Value for the money.  The staff fulfill and even anticipate any desire. Concierge does everything right and on time - makes knowledgeable recommendations, books whatever one needs, gives a complete directions/information package prior to an event and sees you off with unsolicited water, towels, papers... Le Marquis bar - LAST ORDER 12am, but if you are still drinking at 2am they don't go anywhere without complaint! I asked a bartender how did they get home if they stayed late - he said that they didn't - there is a small room in the back where they can stay the night... I had a 2 yr break between visits - remembered exactly what newspapers to bring in the morning per my prior request. Things that you don't see: once I returned to my room while it was being cleaned. Wow! Two maids in tandem with a stern supervisor with a check list, the bed moved and the mattress lifted, so that they can clean every square inch thoroughly. Have you looked under any bed in a hotel recently? Gross. Not here. The pool and the spa? Spotless. The sauna and the onsen have been the same for years..., yet so well maintained as if brand new. Well-oiled machine throughout the hotel and people who not only try to satisfy the customer, but take a big pride in their work. Then the setting, one of the most beautiful gardens in Tokyo, make sure to get the garden view room (even if paying extra). Some folks feel it's a bit out of the way, but I found the location convenient and easily accessible via subway (Yurakucho line Edogawabashi station) and JR (from Meguro station via 5min taxi ride). Finally, for $250-300 the price cannot be beat! Insider info: ask for business packages available - free breakfast, spa and 1 taxi ride within Central Tokyo (Yamanote line). Per review title, I've spent quite some time in this hotel and can almost write a book about it, but I'll leave it for another time...

Chimata-no-kami
New York City, New York

review_body: Having had a very disappointing stay most recently back in the UK, we were feeling a bit wearied by our hotel experiences. No need to worry here at the Chinzanso - if you feel like staying in something of a haven from the bright lights and crowds of central Tokyo, you will find it here. Set in an enchanting garden with a variety of trees, a carp filled lake, a waterfall, small shrines in abundance - even a hill - it is delightful. Not only is the hotel extremely efficiently managed, the staff are all smiling, quick and very helpful and the rooms are extremely spacious and comfortable, the bathrooms excellent and the room service delivered with discretion. And Wifi was rapid and free! We were very happy during our six nights spent here and wouldn't hesitate to return. I was on my own much of the time since my husband was attending a conference which, I have to say, made no impact on we ordinary mortals in the hotel which was something of a relief. The concierge happily found me a wonderful English speaking guide who touted me around the main sights - she introduced me to the joys of the Metro system but when I wasn't with her, I tended to use cabs which is very easy. There is not much to see in the immediate vicinity of the hotel but there is a very pleasant walk by the river through the residential area of Bunkyo and the magnificent modern Roman Catholic cathedral of St Mary, just by the hotel entrance, is a must. Designed by one of Japan's most renowned modern architects, it is a fantastic space. We loved Tokyo - I hope that you do, too.

Great 5 star hotel, a little out of the way... but just worth it, amazing gardens, room so comfortable, we were just spoiled on this last day in Tokyo, after a great trip. The staff is just another level of service, so helpful... We also had some dinner on the bistro restaurant, very nice. and great breakfast in the morning. Our room viewing the garden.

Beautiful gardens in the hotel, tranquil and numerous water features. Very large and comfortable rooms. Location wise, it's a 5 minute walk to the nearest train station but a short train ride to Shibuya, Roppoggi.

This hotel is an real pearl in Tokyo. The luxuous halls gives a first impression that will not stop:- room is very spacious (around 45 m2) with a wonderful view (we took the City View) through a huge window; bathroom propose a big bath and a shower;- the spa not only offers a real onsen segregated between men and women, but also different sauna, a swimming pool and a terrace in the garden,- and of course, the garden: it is just amazing to have such garden with a pagoda, a pound, etc... within the hotel.Definitvely a place to stay one or several night.The hotel is located at 10 minutes by foot from a subway; the bus is really convenient: every 10 minutes, with the Yamanote line at 5 minutes.Note: for such 5 stars hotel in Tokyo, there are special offers around 200 EUR/night for 2 persons.Visité en novembre 2015http://www.tripadvisor.fr/ShowUserReviews-g1066442-d504483-r326507118-Hotel_Chinzanso_Tokyo_Garden-Bunkyo_Tokyo_Tokyo_Prefecture_Kanto.html#

It is not in the city center but commuting is easy in Japan. This hotel has an incredibly beautiful garden. Even if you can't stay, I strongly recommend you to see the garden at least. Also, just opposite to the hotel, you have the cathedral, Catholic.

This is a lovely hotel with excellent service. The walk to the subway was easy (as was the subway itself!), the uphill walk back was not as easy, but not a problem for this mid 50's couple. The beautiful and serene garden on the property was worth the walk and the bridal activities. The restaurants we visited were very enjoyable. Had some difficulty booking at the spa due to language conflicts? If this is a priority (and the spa looks fabulous) I would book in advance of your trip. Highly recommed this hotel!

This is a classic hotel, former four seasons. Rooms are extremely spacious in classic decoration, though not walking distance to subway, taxi is not that bad. Airport limousine stops over but schedule not as frequent. Not to miss Japanese breakfast, which is great. The onsen water are transport form real onsen, also not to miss. Slightly pricey especially in Sakura season but I'm sure it is worth it,

Improved since my last visit in 2013. First visited when it was a Four Seasons and it had slipped by 2013, both in condition and service. Almost didn't rebook but loved the adjacent garden setting. Very glad that they have started bringing it back into shape. Location is a bit isolated, but that's part of the charm to me. Saturday night is a bit busy with all the weddings. Service is great, especially the Concierge. Front desk could improve just a bit though. Paid pool is still a joke, while not uncommon in Japan, a 5 star could do better. Look forward to my next visit as this hotel is a must.

If you desire peace and tranquility, with outstanding decor and service, and top-notch chefs this is the place. My wife and I have been to many top hotels but the Chinzanso is a beauty to enjoy with their own award winning garden. There are no milling crowds, It's Zen. You don't have to cruise all over Tokyo looking for the best restaurants, the Japanese restaurant Miyuki offers a variety of 50 dishes(much never tasted before) is here with the most reasonable price for dinner. Try the boiled eggplant soup and the best udon with dried tofu.The bedroom is so large with the best beds. The bathroom features features many amenities. I better stop now before I gush too much.

We loved this hotel! Its clean, beautiful, the rooms are large. Everything a 5 star hotel should have. They turn down your bed with chocolate, give you 2 bottles of water/day. Our hotel included access to the fitness center and spa which was a real treat. Spa had its own onsen! The gardens are beautiful and they provided you with an umbrella if its raining! It is a good 15-20 minute walk to the nearest subway station so if you are looking for convenience this hotel is not for you. It took us 40-50 minutes to everywhere we wanted to go. We knew this going in but loved the hotel and the quietness of the area.

The Hotel Chinzanso Tokyo is in the middle of a beautiful garden, with a 1000 year old Pagoda, not the hustle and bustle of Tokyo, but this is incredibly refreshing. Rooms are spacious. Staff are very friendly. Multiple options for eating, both in the hotel itself and on the property. A luxury escape that is only a short cab ride (or 30 minute walk) from everything else Tokyo.

Now, there are many first-class hotels in Tokyo, but if you want to stay in a tranquility, out of the hustle and bustle of Tokyo, still this hotel is the place to stay !! The rooms are spacious and clean and you can see the wonderful Japanese Garden from your room. Beds are very comfy and toiletries are L'Occitane. I love the restaurants of this hotel, and also the staffs are very attentive. If you are looking for crowds or nightlife, go to Shinjuku, Ikebukuro, or Shibuya !! But, after your time in those places, it's a great pleasure to come back to this hotel.

Japan is wow, an amazing, clean and, courteous place. But staying here is one of my favorite parts of our entire trip. The court yard is beautiful and the cherry blossoms were amazing and in bloom. The pagoda surrounded by lush gardens and waterfalls made this hotel not feel like we were in a hyper metropolis but instead a hotel of prefect balance.The head concierge was incredible, the town was booked and me a the wife really wanted french and not garden variety either, i told him we wanted an Michelin 2 star or better experience he was on the phone for over an hour and got us a amazing reservation at Pierre Gagnaire looking out on to tokyo tower, where we had the best dinner that've we've had in the past decade.

I love to explore a city on foot, and arriving at this hotel I already got a bad feeling along the long drive from the entrance to the hotel lobby.The staff and reception area are immaculate, the elevator lobby is beautiful green marble, which make open lift doors difficult to see. Staff were excellent and helpful.Anyway, why 3 stars?- Well, on the plus, rooms are big but in urgent need of refurbishment. Cracked tiles in the shower, grouting splintering. Lighting panel shabby.- Restaurant, the "western" breakfast restaurant only has set meals not a buffet and the food took time in coming in busy periods and was not excellent- Generally expensive food - The whole place gave me a sterile feeling (except for the dirt in the crack in the shower)- Isolation, this hotel although in the middle of Tokyo is miles away from anywhere. Even the next metro stop is a considerable hike. You have to use taxis everywhere.The hotel is obviously set up for weddings, the beautiful gardens and huge wedding planning suites. Would not recommend for tourists and for business only if your meetings are close by or in the neighbouring conference center.

One would not go wrong choosing Hotel Chinzanso Tokyo.Starting from prior to arrival, various departments and members of the staff went out of their way to answer our queries - ranging from transportation, hotel booking, etc. All these communications even happened before I committed to staying there. First grade service throughout!The photos found here do not do justice to the hotel as they are only a snapshot of Chinzanso. It is the atmosphere of the reception, the serenity of the garden, the sincerity of the staff and various little things that impress visitors, and these are not convey-able through photographs.We arrived before check-in time and were greeted at the door by someone holding a list with our names on it. There were no tourist groups in the lobby, nobody hanging around aimlessly, no queues at the check-in counter - just a very warm and welcoming reception as if it was not our first visit! We did not mind the least that our room was not ready as the atmosphere was like time standing still giving us a zen-like feeling.We made our way to the subway station most easily with instructions given by the staff at the reception and further clarified by the concierge. It was a leisurely downhill walk through a tree-lined residential area. One could see the state of those little houses, no doubt a pride of their owners/residents. Along the way we saw a neighbourhood bakery and a few convenience stores. Depending on where one wishes to explore, the station is between 2-5 stops from the main shopping areas of Tokyo Station or Shinjuku. If taking a taxi is what one prefers, the fare is about 3500 Yen to Tokyo Station and 2000 or so to Shinjuku, traffic permitting.The room itself was faultless (we didn't smell any cigarette smoke as some people have commented). Little fine touches were noticeable throughout in the decoration, and in the provision of necessities to make us feel special and valued.The washroom itself was top-notched in its decoration and facilities with brand name Occitane and Intellige Ex skin care products for the ladies and house brand shaving cream for the gents!Breakfast was either Japanese or Continental, consumed at two different restaurants. We were delighted and not surprised to find that it was not of the buffet variety. As the seating capacity was limited, a certain amount of waiting was necessary but this was also a very zen-like experience as one could look out onto the garden and absorb the morning glory from within the hotel.Yes, this has become our first choice in Tokyo. For those not looking for the crowds or nightlife, Hotel Chinzanso provides the perfect balance between accessibility and tranquility in Tokyo.

This hotel is brilliant in every way, location is good the staff a brilliant and always want to help you! Rooms are big and clean, and great onsite facilities I.e spa and restaurants and bars, and with its own gardens in the city is really nice and peaceful to walk round. I would definitely recommend this hotel and would definitely stay here again when I visit.

I have stayed here twice this year. Both times the service was excellent. Pros:- Large rooms with a corner window view in every one. Not just large by Japan standards, but large period. - Room service breakfast with toast includes a toaster.- Fast Wifi.- L'Occitane toiletries. Ooh-La-La!- Very comfy bed. Cons:- Restaurants are very pricy. I spent about $40 for a hamburger with a beer, Food is excellent though. - A little out of the way to walk anywhere. If you ask the Concierge they will provide you with a map to get to some noodle or sushi shops nearby.

I stayed for three nights on a business trip. This hotel is located in Bunkyo, close to Kanda River, Waseda University and Takushoku University. For most tourists and business travelers it may seem be a bit off the "city center" (e.g. Ginza), but6 is in fact not too far away. The main reason to chose this hotel anyway would be the park. The hotel has the luxury of being situated at a quite large park, that can be accessed only via the hotel. The park has beautiful walking trails, pagodas, small exquisite restaurants and huge old trees. Absolute bliss this peace and quiet in the buzzing and hectic city of Tokyo.The hotel is the former Four Seasons. Interior design and furniture are of the more heavy, conservative style. As expected in Japan, the hotel is very clean and staff is extremely polite and helpful.Only disappointment I had was with checkin: when I arrived after a long flight from Singapore, I realized in the room that this was a smoking room. So late in the evening and very tired I had to go down to checkin again, and ask for a non-smoking room, as my assistant had clearly requested when booking.The rooms are quite large for Tokyo standards, clean, and -as mentioned- not of the modern but conservative design.Breakfast was good, service a bit slow though. I had also a dinner in the teppanyaki restaurant in the park (forgot the name) which was really good, as well as in the restaurant "The Bistro" which served an excellent Wagyu steak. The hotel bar is OK, but not great: first of all, you need to be able to tolerate loud Australian tourists and really LOTS of cigar and cigarette smoke. I had a Manhatten which was unfortunately only very poorly made.All-in-all a very good choice with some small but tolerable disappointments.

Room was more spacious than what you'd expect from Japanese hotels. Overall decor is classic elegance similar to other hotels in the same category. What made it unique are the lovely gardens connected to the property, offering respite. Dinner at the Japanese restaurant turned out to be especially memorable for the exquisite grilled beef, sashimi, deliciously light tempura and soba. Western breakfast offered a few simple choices and both the healthy and quick breakfast options were excellent. Will take some time compared to a buffet but you can count on the food and service quality.

Hotel Chinzanso is not 'central' to Tokyo. I was there for 4 nights this May and needed to get to and from Shimbashi. For the 25 minute cab ride or 20 minute train journey it was worth being in the peaceful setting.The room itself was large, well appointed and very well maintained. The decor of the hotel is a bit 1990's but surprisingly that was charming, especially with the good service.I will definitely recommend the hotel for the business traveller not obsessed with being closer to Ginza or Shinjuku.

I live in Tokyo, but am here for a business meeting for 2 days. Decided to stay at the hotel because the location is not very convenient -- even for living in Tokyo.The garden is really beautiful and worth seeing. The room is very comfortable and the bed is wonderful.Breakfast is not a buffet, so need to factor that into your morning plan.

Beautiful ambience....classy clean lines and good colours. Staff are very helpful and attentive.Thorough with details to explain your accommodation and the facilities/ attraction of the hotel.Very good size bedrooms and well furnished...good light colour selection and good natural light with great views.The hotel garden on Level 1 and hot spring water pool...are great attraction in themselves.The main bar - Les Marquis has 100 types of Martini mix in the menu - so good!

I have stayed at many "five-star" hotels on business, but I don't know what makes them think they are the "five-star."When checking in, they made us wait for about 10 minutes to escort us to our rooms because they were "short staffed." Nobody was watching over our luggage that we left with the bell man at the front entrance.... I went out there to grab my bag, I didn't see anyone. After a minute or so, a bell man came out and told me that he was watching over our luggage... Not so sure why it took him a minute to come out and check with me if he was "watching over" our luggage...Overall, it felt like that they have different levels of hospitality depending on the status (or the price of the room) of the guest.Don't get me wrong. Their rooms are classy and the garden is beautiful, but their service is not quite "five-star" as they claim.I'm sorry, but for the money I paid, I will definitely choose a different hotel next time.

We stayed at Hotel Chinzanso for 7 nights in April for our trip to Tokyo. It was the best decision we made for our trip.The hotel itself is very classic, reminds me of the glorious days of the Japanese grand hotels. We had a superior room with a king size bed and the city view (we could see the new Tokyo Skytree). The room was spacious, clean and well equipped. I liked the room better than the Aria, Bellagio, Palazzo resort rooms I experienced in Las Vegas. Next time we will try to book a room that was just renovated in 2014.The best part about Hotel Chinzanso is its service. From the initial email contact, the staff was tentative and helpful. The concierge helped us book numerous restaurants in Tokyo, and even prepared an info package with maps to each restaurant. The turn down service was also a nice touch. The included hot spring was simply awesome.All staff we met at the hotel were willing to help and with a smile. We had a great time staying at Hotel Chinzanso. Language was never an issue as most of them can communicate well in English.The restaurants were also memorable. We had a traditional Japanese breakfast at Miyuki which was very good. Go early so you can get the window tables which offers a great view to the Japanese garden. The soba noodle dinner we had at Mucha-an was something special. It was a great experience dining in an old fashioned Japanese building in the huge Japanese garden. The price was very reasonable. Highly recommended.We will definitely choose Hotel Chinzanso again for our next trip to Tokyo.

Our last two nights in Japan so we’d booked something a bit special. We weren’t disappointed. We had a very well appointed room with large windows overlooking the hotel’s gardens and indoor pool. We tried two of the restaurants and found the food to be excellent.The staff were very friendly and couldn’t have been more helpful. Our only disappointment was that we didn’t realise that the hotel provided a shuttle bus to the airport (at a small charge), we found out too late.The hotel is a little bit out of the centre of Tokyo, but is only a 10 minute walk to the nearest underground station.

A lovely hotel set in a residential location in Tokyo. Excellent service, food, & helpful.The only downside is that if you have a short time in Tokyo you are a little out of the main shopping areas. The rooms are large and clean. Very friendly staff.

We had a great stay at this hotel. The rooms were very large and well decorated, beautiful toilets and amenities. They have a breathtaking and peaceful garden. The metro station is a nice 10 minutes stroll away. Every member of staff was super. Really thank you.

We stayed there at the end of our Japan tour with Unique Japan. This is an elegant hotel located at the edge of the beautiful garden it overlooks from high above. Our room had a view of the trees and the city. The room was very nice with a fantastic bathroom. You get first class service and friendliness... and small French Valhrona chocolates at night! . To get anywhere, we walked 10 minutes down the hill to the subway station and to small restaurants and shops including a Seven Eleven whose ATM works with non Japanese credit cards. Another time, we took the free hotel shuttle bus to a large square with lots of department stores and another subway line. Many weddings took place while we were there, always a lovely sight with the beautiful dresses.At the end of our tour, we had a farewell dinner in one of the tearooms in the garden which turned out the best traditional Japanese dinner we had on the entire tour. The room had tables and chairs western style, good for our old bones.

We love this hotel. Access from Narita takes a couple of hours from landing. We took the Skyliner bound for Ueno, changed to the J.R. Yamanote line at the Nippori stop. We took the train to the Meijiro stop. A quick walk across the street to the bus stop for Bus 61. 10 minute bus ride to Chinzanso stop and you're here. The grounds are lovely. The staff are top notch, typical Japanese hospitality but even more pronounced, commensurate with the class of the hotel. The hotel offers breakfast vouchers for either Il Teatro for western style breakfast or Mizuno for Japanese style breakfast. The voucher is for ¥3100 and you can select from set menus. We chose the western style breakfast and it was just okay. We also ordered room service our first night in. Aside from being overpriced (like all room service), it was fine. They have a great variety. The bathrooms are lovely. Private toilet area, deep tub, and a spacious standing shower stall.The gardens are unbelievable. So peaceful and beautiful. The staff is outstanding. We traveled with our one-year-old twins. They have a long list of convenience items for babies and are happy to provide them. We called the desk and asked for diapers as we hadn't had the chance to get to the drugstore. A staff member was at our door in less than 3 minutes with a selection of diapers. They're so helpful.This has been such a relaxing experience. We will certainly be back. I would definitely recommend this hotel to families, especially those with babies.

I only stayed one night, but from the moment I walked up to the door of the lobby, I could not have been made to feel more special. There wasn't a single element I would criticise - the gardens are stunning, the spa superb and the massage was incredible. Without doubt the most professional, tension relieving hour one could experience. It's definitely at the classy and sophisticated end of the hotel scale, rather than a funky, contemporary hotel, but if that's your style of hotel, you will adore it.

Just having spent ten wonderful days in the Chinzanso Hotel we must say the stay has been wonderful. The garden is beautiful.location wise, a good ten minute walk to the closest subway and not an easy WLL on the way back as the hill go the hotel is a little steep, but a nice walk and easy to find the subway.We paid 3000 yen from the hotel to Tokyo Station which is really not so bad.Only negative about the hotel is that there are very few restaurants withing walking distance and the hotel prices are too expensive.

The lobby and rooms are absolutely beatiful. The beds and showers are great. Garden views from the rooms perfectly match the nature sounds that can be played thoughout the bedroom. Staff is friendly and helpful. We were placed in a room with incorrect bed arrangement and they immediately resolved the problem in a calm and pleasant manner. One of the nicest hotels I have ever slept in. Truly marvelous.

What I like the most is the hotel is surrounded by gardens and it has walking path in it. It's so relaxing. All the staff of the hotel are kind and helpful. It's good to families to stay in. Breakfast is delicious and nice, not so many varieties of food though

This is the first time that I stayed in the property since it ceased being a Four Seasons, but to be honest you can't notice the difference. This is a very good hotel, with beautiful grounds and good facilities. It is a bit annoying that prices in the bar (and in the mini-bar!) are outlandishly expensive, but that's life. Overall this property never disappoints, and I would certainly come back again.

We had the impression we were the only non-Japanese in the hotel but were made to feel very welcome during our entire stay. The staff were wonderfully friendly and professional and the hotel itself is spotless, beautiful and the garden is a tranquil getaway in this mega-capital which is constantly busy. If you go just north of the hotel you can find quaint shops and small local restaurants that do not cost a fortune (the hotel restaurants are wonderful but pricey). But I do recommend the Japanese Grill restaurant. Outstanding food and service and a unique experience. We would both go again any time we visit Tokyo.

This Hotel used to be Four Seasons years ago. Very effective check in and friendly staff guide you to your room. Large room with all you need. Large bathroom with comfy shower. Also comfy bed. Liked the gym too in the second floor. Will be back!

I'm fortunate enough to have stayed at a number of supposedly upmarket hotels. They often fail to live up to expectations. A superficial veneer of 'luxury' typically overlays poor service, incompetent staff and inadequate maintenance. The Chinzanso was a welcome and refreshing exception to this rule and delivered in full on its five star promise. Very welcoming staff, comfortable room, excellent gym and an air of understated luxury throughout. Not very convenient for public transport and more than US$10 for a cup of coffee in the restaurant - but otherwise excellent, if expensive.

A perfect getaway during a recent business trip. Rooms were spacious, beautifully appointed, staff helpful with anything I needed (or forgot)...and the gardens were a perfect place to walk and unwind at the end of the day.

Excellent service in a great hotel. Beautiful garden. Expect no half measures at this hotel. Even the breakfast is a sit down affair with no buffet. A great place for a romantic 1-2 days away. Staying with children is fine but without adds a special touch. Not a great location though. About a 10-15 min walk up or down quite a steep hill unless you can enter/exit the gate in the hotel garden before 9pm. Then about a 10 min walk to Edogawabashi Stn on the Yurakucho Line.

What a lovely bit of relaxation and charm away from the hustle of Tokyo. The rooms were the most luxurious of our entire Japan trip. The lobby was a never-ending enjoyment of interesting people, many in traditional kimonos. There were also beautiful paintings and exquisite porcelain vases. The outside gardens were spectacular. One night we walked to the soba restaurant on the grounds of the hotel. The concierge service was friendly and helpful with suggestions for touring.The drawback was that the hotel was a bit for from restaurants in the area. The breakfast was delicious (a welcome sit down service, not buffet) and was included as part of our room rate.

I stayed here with my family during the Christmas Holiday. A great hotel with nice rooms, lobby, restaurant and breathtaking garden. But one thing I want to point out is the service, the staff were very helpful and attentive! Staff service is more than excellent! The only down side is the location of the hotel, it is quite far from the city center and the nearest train station is quite far. But overall a great hotel!

I have never stayed in a hotel that is so beautiful, our stay here was perfect from the minute we walked into the hotels gardens to when we left. we had no problem finding the hotel from the tube station, and were met with a smile and a map from the very nice gentlemen by the start of the gardens who explained where we should go. On getting to the reception desk we were greeted with a smile and asked to wait, apologies for a small delay, and we were checked, we had two lovely ladies who took us to our room, one to carry our bags and the other who explained the hotel to us, and on getting to the room drew the curtains and explained the view which was truly amazing.The bathroom was vast, a separate bath and huge shower, l'occitane products, razors, toothbrushes etc. There is a large wardrobe, slippers, bathrobes, safe, fridge and mini bar, coffee machine. Huge TV, power points for charging iPads etc.they turn down the beds, put out mats for you to step on chocolate, weather forecast for the next day. what more could you ask for. the bed was so comfortable pillows a dream.the gardens are a joy to walk through, and the laser show in the evening was awesome.Every member of staff was polite and helpful and always a smile on their faces. I would certainly stay here again if I ever get back to Tokyo. It was a dream stay from start to finish, A perfect hotel,

Great place to stay in a quiet neighborhood. Options are limited outside of the hotel property but some late night restaurants are within a 10-15 minute walk. Massive complex with many restaurant options. Be prepared to pay for it. Lovely property and gardens. Service was spot-on. Rooms are very spacious and probably the largest you're going to find in Tokyo.Massive disappointment for us was Expedia booking clearly showed "Spa Access Included". When we went to use the pool they told us it was an extra Y4300pp. They would allow us to use the treadmills but not the pool. Not sure if it was bait/switch or an Expedia mistake but still a let down for our experience at the Chinzanso. Restaurants also closed at 10pm on the nights we stayed there but it was during holiday season. I believe usual closing hours are 11pm. The hotel does offer 24h room service.If you're looking for a relaxing time in Tokyo you should consider Chinzanso.

We enjoyed our stay and would recommend to anyone. Close to public transport and friendly staff. Had a lovely meal in the hotel one night. Lovely bathroom with a lot of space. Comfortable beds. We had a room overlooking the gardens, and it was beautiful.

Staying at the Hotel Chiinzanso was the perfect introduction to our first trip to Tokyo and to Japan. From the very first greeting of the smiling and friendly staff to the final farewell, nothing could be faulted. Our room was spacious, with excellent facilities and had an excellent view of the Hotel Gardens and the City. The Gardens are beautiful. You can take a leisurely stroll through them to either enjoy the surrounds or to reach many of the Hotel Restaurants. We enjoyed delicious meals in three of the Hotel Restaurants. The Hotel is a short walk from the Metro and the centre of Tokyo and its many Tourist attractions can be reached either by Taxi or train. We were able to negotiate the Japaese Train System without too much trouble even after all the frightening stories we had heard. All staff members should be congratulated on their performance, friendliness and work ethic. I have no hesitation in recommending this Beautiful Hotel. It is certainly Five Star for me!!!!!

We stayed here in November for 4 nights, it's an amazing hotel. We were in the newly remodeled room, so luxurious ... they thought of everything. The amenities are first class, i.e., Nespresso coffee maker and L'occitane bath products. We had a wonderful view of the garden, leaves were changing colors ... didn't feel like we were in the middle of Tokyo! At night they have a light show in the garden, we could watch it from our room. Be sure to take time to walk around the garden, so serene. the food was also excellent! i would highly recommend this hotel and can't wait to return, be sure to try their Japanese breakfast!

We stayed at Hotel Chinzanso in April 2014. Being our first time ever in Japan, we were surprised by the breathtaking nature which we saw a lot of in the area around the hotel. Chinzanso is located in a part of Tokyo that is far away from the business and shopping areas, and that is only to its advantage. We loved coming back to the hotel after a day shopping. What we liked about this hotel was first and foremost the garden and the little restaurant in it where we were served a magnificent 7-course dinner with a chef cooking the food in front of us. The kobe-beef was amazing. One negative thing is that we were charged to use the swimming pool.Over all we really enjoyed our stay!

We stayed at Chinzanso in October 2014. The property is beautiful being former residence of one of major clan of Japan. The hotel is in the middle of this enormous garden, you must spend time to spend time to stroll around the garden if you decided to stay here. Staff are very helpful and everything are beautiful. It's just the location being not ideal but they have free bus service from Ikebukuro station and a subway station is not very far. I wish I had enough time to try all the restaurants in the garden. I will definitely stay here again.

Stayed at this hotel for two nights last week while in Tokyo on November 11th and 12th. All I can say is Oh my God was this hotel fantastic.We had a view of the park behind the hotel and on Tuesday night we went to eat at the Ramen restaurant in the park and we got a guided tour of the park from the hotel staff.Everything about this hotel was immaculate and we will definitely stay again during our nest visit to Tokyo.It's not to far from Shinjuku and Ikebukuro and only about a 2000 yen taxi ride.

Enjoyed every seconds inside the hotel property. Top-notch service and room and amenities. Huge, breathtaking garden scenery. Popular for wedding for rich couples. Among the best hotels I've stayed in throughout my travels around the world. The only downside is its location. Tokyo is expensive, so is its land. So far the hotel to occupy such large piece of land it's up on the hills away from downtown.

This kind of hotel would normally be out of my price range and I wouldn't even consider it as an option. However I decided to treat myself at the end of an arduous adventure in Japan and got a decent deal by booking well in advance. For the first few hours I was actually deeply uncomfortable and felt out of place; me arriving all sweaty and dusty with my backpack in their palatial lobby, being fawned over by the faultlessly attentive staff... I thought I had made a horrendous mistake. However. Once I'd settled down and scrubbed myself up a bit I began to relax, and eventually had a wonderful couple of days in this unique hotel. As is well known, space is like gold dust in Tokyo, so for a hotel to have a 17 acre garden is quite something. I've certainly never had a better view from a city hotel room window. I particularly enjoyed the main bar (although fusspots should note that smoking is permitted in there) and the astonishing garden. I didn't visit any of the twelve restaurants but had a peek at a couple and they looked fabulous. The room I was in was superb, and the bathroom was probably the best I've experienced.Not my favourite hotel ever because it wasn't really "me", but I can't think of a single negative thing to say about it, so it's five stars and a "highly recommended".

I stayed at the Hotel Chinzanso for 5 nights. Nice hotel, but... - no place to get an inexpensive meal (anything less than $35)  - cracked and peeling paint on the ceiling of my bathroom - and a 2 inch cockroach greeted me in the bathroom this morningI would not recommend it, there are better hotels in Tokyo - Cerulean, New Otani

We had a great time at Hotel Chinzanso. Large and luxury room and bath. We experienced a high tea which we recommend absolutely. The Spa is a must. Dinner at il Teatro was fantastic. Don't forget to make a walk in the beautiful garden.Excellent breakfast, where it is possible to choose between Japanese and western style.Staff were very friendly and helpful. Thanks to all staff.

We arrived tired after an 11 hour flight, and a 90 minute bus ride from the airport. Our bags were taken away from us at the door, we were shown to a seat while they sorted out check in, and then we were taken up to our room on the 12 floor. A flawless welcome! The Japanese people take a pride in what they do, which makes it a pleasure to visit their lovely country, and they do not act that way because they want you to tip them either! If only it was like that back in the UK or US! When we arrived we were not told about the hotel facilities, so we wandered around later that day and found a small room on our floor called the Pagoda Lounge with coffee making facilities and a range of teas available, but for some reason the room was only open until 6pm. I think management should review this as it would have been nice for guests to have been allowed to sit in there in the evening and watch the night descend on Tokyo. Throughout our stay the staff could not have been nicer or more helpful. They bow when you walk past, which seems really strange when you first encounter it, but this was not our first trip to Japan and we appreciated their courtesy and respect. They all speak some English, but most, not brilliantly. The only reason why I have given this hotel 4 stars instead of 5 is the breakfast We paid in advance 3,000 yen per breakfast and you receive a set of vouchers that you must take down to breakfast with you. If you only want some toast, pastries and coffee, don't pay in advance as the tokens cost more than the cost of the continental breakfast.On our first morning we were given a menu and a glass of freshly squeezed orange juice. I ordered scrambled eggs and bacon. There was also a bread basket on the table with lightly cooked toast, a croissant, a couple of pastries and two muffins. That day in particular, service was very slow. Eventually the scrambled egg arrived with a salad swimming in dressing and American style crispy cooked bacon. I'm sorry, but I just did not like the breakfast. For one thing I do not want a dressed salad for breakfast, and we found that every breakfast you order has the salad. Why do they do that? The scrambled eggs looked like vomit on a plate, I only wish I had taken a picture of it so you could see what I mean. It just looked awful, hardly cooked and very runny. That morning I just ate the crisp bacon and the toast, and left the rest. From that point on I ordered the continental breakfast, which is orange juice, tea / coffee and the breadbasket, which for 1,800 yen must be the most expensive toast in the world. On day 4 my husband tried the Japanese breakfast. Now that was worth eating, so do try it. One person I do want to mention was a female waitress who served us. She made sure that our toast was properly cooked when I asked for it to be well toasted and warm, and she was very attentive in other ways too. The name on her badge was A Wright and I asked to be sat each morning in her area. I have been critical up to now, and I feel bad doing it, because [ I really enjoyed my stay at the Chinzanso. Yes, we paid a lot for cabs because the hotel is a little way out, but reviews on here had warned us about that, so we expected to do this, and there was no problem in finding our way around. As for the facilities, they are what you would expect in a hotel of this size. The rooms were large and comfortable, the bed was good, and the air conditioning was the quietest I have ever known in a hotel. The bathroom has a bath and separate shower, which I was delighted to find as I cannot manage to step into a bath whenever I want a shower. Typically a Japanese person will wash in the shower and then relax in the bath, so it is not unusual to find this in a Japanese hotel. It also has the usual Toto toilet, which is has all sorts of extras not found in a European toilet.Other reviewers have mentioned that they did not receive the toiletries they required, but we found the supplies were plentiful, and our room was well cared for by the cleaning staff who left the room spotless, even to the point of tidying up our work papers, which we had just thrown down on a chair. Twice a day they left a Japanese newspaper hanging in a bag outside our door. There were English newspapers in the breakfast room which you could take away with you. There is a kettle in the room, which was useful too, and the inevitable bar / refrigerator, but they give you a complimentary bottle of water every evening when they turn down the beds. Our room had a lovely angular window that looked right over Tokyo and the curtains were opened using a switch found in the top drawer of the bedside table. We used room service on the day we arrived, and the food arrived quickly on one of those cabinets that convert into a table. Again no tip was expected. I hate going to hotels where you have to tip staff if they smile at you, we stayed recently at a hotel in Washington that was like that and it was really annoying, and expensive! In contrast, the Chinzanso was so relaxing, the staff were approachable and I didn't have to think all the time: "do I tip this person, or not".This is a large hotel, with a beautiful garden as others have mentioned, and there is a deck which also is laid out as a garden on the 5th floor. We might have made more use of the facilities had we been told in advance what they were. I got totally lost on the second day when trying to find the garden, there were no signs to the door. A friend who lives in Tokyo warned us that they had cases of dengue fever which is spread by mosquitos, so it was good to see some bottles of mosquito repellent on the 5th floor and by the front door. That was very considerate of them.This is a hotel that has to be wandered around. We found a bar, but it was smoky so we did not stay too long. In the UK we do not have smoking in public places, and that suits us fine. There were various restaurants, some shops, a pool that we did not use, and wifi worked well, and was free too. It really annoys me when you pay a lot for a hotel room, and then they expect you to pay for wifi, and there are hotel chains I do not use because of that. Apart from breakfast, this place and its staff was faultless. On our last morning we had to leave early, and it looked like we were going to miss breakfast, however they prepared for us a take out bag and could not have been more helpful in organising our bags and loaded them on a shuttle for us. I have stayed in other hotels in Tokyo and Kyoto and the service is always good, and you can expect the rooms to be clean and tidy, but there was something special about this hotel. You felt that the staff did that little bit extra to help you. A couple of things to add, across the road is a lovely church and next door is a garden centre with a little cafe and a museum. Do not miss the museum, which is only small, but it has some great paintings in there. The hotel is in two parts, and the bus stops next door so if you want to use the bus, you do not need to go outside the grounds. Cabs are plentiful, and are always outside the front door. When we first turned on the TV there is some advice about what to do in an earthquake. Watch it. While we were there we experienced an earthquake; the ground shook for a bit and then stopped, so it is worth knowing what to do in the hotel, just in case.

Inside a Japanese Park, with beautiful and spacious room. 30 / 40 minutes from Tokyo station.Taxi all over the night and 10 minutes walking to metro stationSeems to stay on a Japanese palace with all the attention of a Luxury Hotel.Expensive but I will come back

This place is paradise especially if you are from the states. Plenty of room which is amazing because it's Japan. Large rooms even by american standards. That's just the beginning though.I have never stayed at a nicer place with the best service. The people there are amazing and are literally second to none. The garden is a miracle of nature in the middle of a metropolis, you hear no street noise. I can't verbalize the excellence of the people and the property. I'll say it again, if you can stay there, stay there. The location has been given negative comments but it wouldn't be physically possible for it to be anywhere else. It's in the middle of everything and history. Amazing amazing amazing.

Just what I needed: a very relaxing weekend in Tokyo with pampering! The hotel staff, from check-in to check-out, made me feel as though I was their main priority. The restaurants offer exquisite eating. I especially recommend Camilla, where the chef went out of his way to accommodate my lactose-intolerance. Many thanks to our host for the evening. Andre ensured we met all of our connections promptly and had a effortless check-out. And the garden... having a garden at our very own disposal was such a welcomed retreat from the hustle and bustle of busy Tokyo. The design of the garden is such that you felt as though you could walk in it all day and not see the same corner twice! Just perfect.

Very nice hotel, used to be named as "Fourseasn" but quality is still same as before. They have natural firefly in their Japanese garden and only place in central Tokyo! The pool has a hot spring bath bringing from Hakone.

The hotel was exceptional. My gf and I booked it with a tour package through HIS's Destination Japan's website. It was actually part of a tour package as well. The hotel was a bit pricey but worth every penny! The staff were always extremely professional and helpful even with my rudimentary Japanese. The view and gardens around the hotel were beautiful. We were able to experience a special tea ceremony with the package as well! This hotel also included an onsen which was something that my gf and I were very interested in. I would recommend this hotel and tour package to anyone traveling to Tokyo, or Japan for that matter.

Stayed here for a short summer getaway hoping to relax and enjoy the garden, food, and atmosphere. Before checking in, we decided to have lunch at Le Jardin. Unfortunately, the restaurant does not cater to those with dietary restrictions. There were no vegan options available so I was unable to eat. This is understandable at a 2 or 3 star hotel, but completely unacceptable at a hotel that describes themselves as "Luxury Hotel Tokyo, 5 Star". I expect a much higher level of service at a hotel of this class. Clearly, their rating needs to be changed. The hotel features the "Pagoda Lounge" which is a lounge area with free coffee, tea, and reading materials. I spent some time here on my first day relaxing and viewing the garden. On my second day, I returned at opening time to find it closed without any sign or notice. After a 20 minute wait, we were informed by the staff that it was moved to a lower floor. Unbelievable. Again, not the kind of serve I expect at a "5 Star" hotel. Other than the problems above, the room was spacious, and had a great view of the garden. The furniture and design though, are a bit dated and dirty. As for the location, it is a bit inconvenient for tourists, especially those who are unfamiliar with the transportation system in Tokyo. I understand this used to be a Four Seasons property. What a big change, this place is nowhere near the level of service a Four Season Hotel provides. I hope the hotel changes their "5 Star" rating and if not, then at least live up to the standards of service. Until then, I would not recommend this hotel to anyone expecting a 5 Star experience and have no interest in returning.

We had a great experience at Hotel Chinzanso where we stayed for four nights as part of a group conference. Memorable. The huge largely camellia garden with a pagoda, waterfall, and many other features was amazing. We walked around it at least twice a day, changed with the sun and the weather. The hotel is a former Four Seasons, now independent, and very competently managed. It is kept very well as it appears to be a major wedding site, we enjoyed watching at least 5 different weddings during the Saturday we were there. Hard to tell as there were kimonos, colored lavish gowns and traditional western white gown in abundance. Breakfast which was included could be either Japanese or western. Both were great. Wonderful Japanese plate of varied choices, and truffled eggs Benedict with fresh shaved truffles. Our room was spacious and modern. Great view of the garden and pagoda from a large circular window. Great bath, shower, separate WC, and heated floors. Towels and bed linens were luxurious. Beds very comfortable.The concierge who we consulted often as this was our first trip to Japan was so helpful with a variety of questions and requests. The restaurants, only some of which we were able to sample looked excellent. Excellent pastries and Japanese candies in the gift shop. We enjoyed an excellent quick pasta dinner in the Italian restaurant when we arrived late the first night. Although not centrally located we had no trouble with transportation. An elegant hotel with superior amenities, and a truly memorable garden. Great for a stay, and not bad for a wedding either!

Don't go to Tokyo without experiencing this Hotel. We stayed in many 5 star hotels in Tokyoand this is still our favorite. We were so happy we are sending are daughter there in a few weeks for the week-end before she returns to the U.S.The staff is absolutely superb.

The rooms are very large and come with L'Occitane amenities. The room had a very nice view of Tokyo at night time and its nice to watch while sitting in the comfortable chairs that the rooms have. The hotel really feels like a luxury hotel and you can see that from decorations, all the way to the staff which provided excellent service. Distance from the subway is a bit far, but we made use of the free shuttle service to Ikebukuro that runs (half?) hourly to visit the center. For us it was actually a good thing that this hotel is located in such quiet area. We could enjoy the busy city atmosphere during the day, and relax in a peaceful and quiet neighbourhood in the evenings. One of the highlights of the hotel is the garden, which is free of charge for guests and non-guests.

Let's start with the bad points:1) Walking from the subway station can be a bit taxing, especially after the entrance through the garden is closed (around 10ish). We had no problems finding a taxi after getting out from the subway though, and there are always taxis waiting in front of the hotel, so no loss of time.2) Communication with the spa is difficult. I wanted to offer my mother a treatment for her birthday, and despite several mails AND an offer to pay beforehand AND a visit in order to confirm that there should be no mention of the costs, the lady in charge of the treatment still had to tell her what the room would be charged. I did not like much the small envelope slid below the door to remind me either. Still, the treatment was good, and I guess that is all that matters.Apart from that, the staff was wonderful and the beds are great (best sleep we had in Japan). We only had the western breakfast and it was filling, despite being à-la-carte.   Will definetly stay there next time I go to Tokyo

Not only registered guests also public people can enter and walk around the beautiful garden. This hotel is located in the central area of Tokyo, but, its garden is beautiful and leafy. Every weekend, many wedding parties are held in the hotel. So, you can see the traditional Japanese wedding suit here.

This is a wonderful luxury hotel, from the moment you want in the you walk in the door, a wonderful experience. The room is comfortable, the service impeccable, the garden lovely. The hotel caters to a lot of weddings, so there is lot of amenities and expensive restaurants. The directions to the hotel are excellent, I took the bus from the airport which was convient and inexpensive.The only caveat is that the hotel is located away from the busy active center of the city. This is great for people looking to get away from the crowds. Also, the style is classic but with elements of the traditional, but not the bright and modern style of Tokyo.Enjoy the garden and the walk among the camelia's.

Finding a spot to "de-stress" in Tokyo can be a challenge. This hotel provides an oasis from the bee-hive of activity that is part of the energy and charm of Tokyo. The reception at the door, at the desk, and the escort to your room sets a new standard in service in my experience. The rooms are quite, clean, clean, and did I mention clean. The real treat of this hotel is its gardens and grounds that demand a walk and some quite time. The food and service at the restaurants in the hotel meet the same standard of excellence for the hotel.It is not the least expensive hotel in Tokyo but the best value to what it does cost. You cannot put a price on service and tranquility.

We had a wonderful stay here on our trip to Japan. The rooms are large and clean, there is very little noise from other rooms or the hallway. The food is good, and of course the staff was very attentive. The garden is spectacular and you get a lovely view from the breakfast restaurant. Tip: if you are ordering the "American Breakfast" get the crispy bacon - the "not crispy" version is something a little bizarre that I couldn't eat. The subway is a five minute walk and we found it relatively easy to navigate.

Stayed only for one night but it was spectacular. The gardens are beautiful, the rooms was very spacious and the service was off the chart - 7 stars. I was greeted by name as I got out of the car (still not sure how they knew it was me - never stayed there before). My sheet was ready for check-in at reception, when I picked up bags from the concierge they magically appeared in 15 seconds - amazing. Wifi was very functional (a pet peeve in many other hotels), bathrooms were generous. The hotel is somewhat removed from downtown Tokyo, but the hotel has generous shuttle services. Will definitely stay again. Obviously, getting a garden view room would be a plus.

New York City, New York

review_body: Stayed here for 3 nights at the beginning of April. We arrived very early and the hotel staff did everything they could to get us into our room before the check in time which we were very thankful for since we had just arrived from London on a 12 hour flight.We had an executive suit with a view of the garden which was amazing. I'd recommend you ask for a high floor garden view when you make the booking. The executive suite was very comfortable and had a large bathroom. It was very clean and the house keeping staff did a great job of keeping the suite clean and tidy while we were out.Breakfast in the hotel was nice enough, but be warned that there is usually a queue ( approx 25 mins wait )around 730am so i'd recommend going around these times if you don't want to wait. As an alternative you can pick up a free coffee and mini muffin in the hotel lobby between 5 and 8am which I took advantage of some mornings ! During the stay my partner made use of the spa for a back massage and was delighted with the experience. Hotel bar is nice and relaxing with a decent selection of whiskys and cocktails, although do be aware that smoking is permitted in the bar. Overall very pleased with the stay and as you expect in Japan the hotel staff were only too friendly.

I stayed here for 3 nights for a conference. Very large comfortable room. Although the furnishings were a little outdated, the room met all my requirements. I had a view over the gardens which are outstanding. Lovely place to relax at the end of the day. Only downside was the actual location to the CBD and the expensive food.

Alice Springs, Northern Territory, Australia

review_body: very nice place in classic style. one of the biggest plus of these hotel - they provide all what you need. Beautiful garden and temple, infrastructure. A lot of bars and restaurants - one of them offer menu with 100 cocktails.English speaking staff.Minus - high prices. Breakfast was not included.

Former a Four Seasons Hotel, now Chinzanso Hotel obviously focuses more on japanese customs, especially for weddings. Nevertheless, due to the fact that wedding parties are held in the Chinzanso Annex, the Hotel itself is a wonderful oasis of peace and calm, beautiful rooms with sight on the huge, magnificent garden, great SPA (only for Hotel Guests) and Onsens.Only negative point: the Room Service Menu is smaller and less interesting then under Four Seasons management. The Breakfast (in room) needs improvements: only 1 juice, only 1 beverage, only either toasts or pastry - everything else extra charged..... not up to date nowadays, with inferior hotels offering huge buffets.....But you will enjoy the calm rooms and the very nice service (especially Danielle at the Concierge!!!!)
