review_body: We began our Japan trip staying in Tokyo for 2 nights at Hotel Chinzanso. I wasn't sure what to expect, but we received a straight forward drop off to the hotel from Narita Airport via the Airport Limousine bus service. It is a lovely hotel and we had requested two interconnecting rooms for our two children and ourselves. The rooms I would have to say were the largest I've seen in Japan and they were beautifully appointed. Some may say they are a little outdated, but I found them to have all the mod con's required and comfort was definitely the focus. My only issue were the pillows - I requested a foam pillow and was delivered the biggest heaviest rice pillow I have ever seen and it was almost too heavy to lift let alone sleep on, so I reverted back to the down pillow. The bar was a great place to have a few drinks after dinner and the breakfast room provided a great al a carte option. We didn't have dinner there as it was incredibly expensive and so we found a local pub to experience the local cuisine. Although the location of the hotel is a little way out, as a result its incredibly quiet and peaceful for sleeping and the garden and pool was of a great size compared to other hotels closer into the CBD. However it was easily accessible to the trains (5 min walk) so that was not a deterrent at all. The hotel were also kind enough to provide us with a transit to Tokyo Station upon our departure as we were on our way to the snow and knew we wouldn't be able to fit into the cab with all our luggage. I would definitely consider Hotel Chinzanso again and we will definitely be back to Japan for a family holiday.

Located in a beautiful historic garden, the hotel offers good restaurants and an excellent hotel staff. There is also a complete health spa. Opt for a room with a garden view and you will not be disappointed. The rooms are large and comfortable. The downside is its location. Unless you have a car at your service, it is a 10-15 minute walk downhill to the nearest subway station, which means an uphill walk at the end of the day. Personally I found the decor uninspired and felt that the hotel could benefit from a re-do, but that should not be the reason not to stay there. If it wasn't for the location I would stay there again.

For a person like me who knows only English it is difficult to get by in a country like Japan. But my stay at the Hotel Chinzanso in Tokyo completely bowled me over as the staff was able to converse with me in reasonably good English. The hotel, though on the pricier side, is a great place to stay and its facilities are superb. This hotel, perhaps apart from a property in Bangalore, India, has a massive garden perfectly manicured and I call it the perfectly manicured forest. If you stay in this hotel anytime, do spend time in the night especially the garden and you will like it and may be bring your children and catch fireflies with them the next time. The food is excellent with great choice – both Japanese and Western. My stay at the Chinzanso would qualify as a blend of the modern with the traditional.

We stayed at the Hotel Chinzanso in September for 4 days and it was fabulous. The rooms were massive and clean, with a beautiful view, luxurious amenities (l'Occitane products), and lots of little extra details that elevated the whole experience. The breakfast was filling and delicious - very authentic and better than any Japanese breakfast we could imagine. The gardens are beautiful and we did a free tour from the guest relations team, as well as a traditional Japanese tea ceremony which was one of our highlights of Tokyo.The location is slightly out of the way as you have to walk about 5-10 minutes to get to the metro but we certainly did not mind as the neighbourhood was wonderful and safe and gave us some much needed exercise. Overall, a great experience and would highly recommend this hotel.

I booked this hotel last minute, and was pleasantly surprised at the deal I was given. The room was large, luxurious, the bathroom very well appointed with fluffy towels and l'Occitane products.The view was fantastic. Arriving at the hotel, the greeting was warm and friendly. I'd found finding wifi in japan challenging, but it was everywhere in this hotel.I would have give it 5 stars, but when I checked out, the receptionist was very abrupt, to the point of rudeness. I understand that we all have busy mornings, busy times at work, but when you work in hospitality, the smile should always be 'on'. It was a real shame.Otherwise, an excellent hotel, nicely away from the melee, a real oasis of calm, but within easy reach of the metro.

I am surprised that this hotel is rated by TA as 4.5 stars, instead of 5!This is a classy establishment, as exemplified by the the anticipatory attentiveness of Ian Jordan, a Guest Relations Manager. Ian approached us on check with an easy charm and with a ready willingness to assist in any way. Thank you Ian for making our stay for special.It is evident that no expense was spared when the hotel was constructed. The design, finishes and furnishings are supremely elegant. The rooms are beautifully appointed in a traditional style. Our room was particularly spacious with a large bathroom with bath and separate shower and separate WC. The real test however is a hotel's response to a problem. We had a hiccup with our first breakfast, which engendered a complaint. The Hotel's response was immediate and complete.As an aside, i note earlier comments as to locality, being problematic. My view differs to the extent that there is bus 61 which stops outside the hotel. it runs every five minutes and terminates at Shinjuku Station in the centre of the metropolis. It is an easy 10 minute pleasant walk to the underground and a 25 minute walk to the JR station at Mejiro. Not a problem!

No one would guess that they were in the middle of the world's most populous city...this ultra quiet and green hotel makes everyone feel like a special guest in a forest garden. After experiencing the spacious and modern guest rooms and bathrooms and restaurant choices, I don't think I'll look for another hotel in the future.

What a retreat! Even with our 13 month old our trip to Japan was lovely. This hotel was the peace we needed when we stepped out of the super busy and congested city. It is elegantly decorated, it's extremely clean which I loved and the staff was so courteous and helpful. Despite the language barriers they did all they could to make us feel warm and welcomed. I felt comfortable with my baby on the floor in the hotel. He even took a bath (which I would never let happen in the states). The food was amazing. The location was a bit out of the city but a 5 min cab ride could get you right into the main city center area. I highly recommend this hotel.

This hotel used to be a four seasons and the hotel fit out and service is still at that level. Rooms are spacious and have good views. It is also rare for Tokyo to have so much open space including an amazing garden which is understandably really popular for weddings. We managed to get a very good rate at the lastminute (40% off) which made it really good value, especially as they accommodated our two young kids in the same room. The main drawbacks are that it is not that convenient for getting around town as you have to take a cab to the nearest station (about US$10) and the food and beverage is seriously expensive (for example a draft beer in the bar is 15 bucks). However, in my view the inconvenience is made up for by the tranquility of the setting and if you are sightseeing in Tokyo its actually really nice to have the contrast by coming back here in the evening. The pool is really nice but like alot of Japanese hotels it is not always included in your rate.

This was my first time to Tokyo and I had an enjoyable stay at this hotel. My room was spacious and clean and the staff couldn't have been more friendly and helpful. I understand that this hotel is older but my room was fine and even had a sweeping view of the gardens which was an added plus! I couldn't wait to walk around the peaceful and beautiful garden. I liked having the choice of either dining in at their restaurants or walking around the neighborhood and finding several places to eat cheaply. And I even discovered a jogging path near the hotel...which was an extra bonus! My only negative was that the hotel was a distance from the airport and that I had to take a taxi to get to another hotel to pick up a shuttle for the city tour. Overall, I found this hotel to be an excellent place to stay!

Great hotel.. Yes its an older hotel from the late 80's or 90's, but it's still clean, fresh, and well kept. (even better then some newer modern ones Ive been too) The hotel service was great from checking in, to booking our excursions, to the room service at 3am. Staff were knowledgeable about the tours and the surrounding area. The hotel is a bit of a walk to the nears train station, so stop for coffee or a snack along the way. The room was huge compare to european and usa standards, with the bathroom being another hotel room in it self. Be sure to take advantage of the beautiful gardens as they are a sight in themselves.

Surrounded by the hustle and bustle of Tokyo, Hotel Chinzanso provides a welcome oasis of calm and tranquility. In the center of the complex is the stunningly tranquil Botanical Gardens. In the midst of over 10,000 trees, you will find the history of Japan. The three story pagoda sits in promence overlooking the garden. The silent gardian wtches over the 500 year old sacred tree, Han'nya-Ji style stone lanterns, the Koshin tower, the Shiratama Inari shrine, and the Seven Deities of Good Fortune. It is an amazing and unexpected pleasure.With the rooms you will find them spacious and well appointed.The restaurants are an epicurian dream. We especially enjoyed the Mokushun-do Restaurant. Sitting at our table, the chef prepared our dinner at the lava stone grill. This is not a meal to be rushed thru, this is truly a sybaritic experience. Our guest, a Tokyo native, was awed by the variety and quality of the repast.The staff is one of the friendliest, best trained, that I have ever experienced in all my travels.This is true 5-star hotel.

I lived in Chinzanso on July 4-11 2013 as my last stay in the trip to Toyko. I rate it "excellent" is not because I look for a modernized hotel. I look for a service + quality hotel that can make you feel your are in holiday. Though a lot of people said this hotel is old and no longer under the name of Four Seasons, honestly, I think it is a worth to try hotel. Hotel breakfast (Japanese Style) has seafood congee. No 1 taste! Rooms are large and western style. You can also choose Japanese Style. The garden is large and special. Only drawback is transportation. If you take bus nos 61, it can stop in front of hotel. But you have to meet the last bs schedule in downtown area. (Around 9:40pm) it is not bad as you can have bus and subway ( can take the last train after 12:00am and take a taxi ~980¥ only back to hotel.Hot spring is also good and impressive. Why not try?

the rooms are huge by Tokyo standards, the gym is really impressive, the pool area like a roman bath. altough not located centrally it was nice to be away frmo the bussle of Tokyo. the gardens are beautiful

We stayed at Chinzanso in June, for 5 days. This hotel was great. It has wonderful picteresque garden, where you can even get lost. We got lucky and saw the fireflies at nigth in this graden. This sight was unforgottable. This hotel is situated on very cosy and calm Mejiro street. This street became our new disovery of Tokyo. At the same time is rather close to the city center. There is a bus stop near the hotel and it takes only 10 minutes to get to Mejiro JR station.The room was very spacious, cosy and elegant. The beds are the softest, it is just a pleasure to sleep on them.As to the breakfasts, they are served a la carte. You have choice between japanese and western restaurants, Breakfasts in both restaurants are rich and various.The staff is very friendly and always ready to help. In addition, they speak english fluently.This hotel has old traditions, it is true 5-star hotel, that worth staying in Tokyo, The stay was rather expensive, but it was well worth the money.

The hotel is gorgeous and is located in a relatively quiet residential area. It may not be the most handy location if you are sight-seeing in Tokyo but the Metro station is in walking distance and there are buses stopping at the hotel door. The hotel room is spacious with quality finish though a little dated and tired. There is a nice Japanese garden attached and you can see Hotaru(glowworm) between late May and July. At the end of the garden, there is an exit (closes at 9pm) to a walking path along the river to Edogawabashi metro station (takes about 5 minutes). The path is more or less flat and shady if you wish to avoid the uphill walk. If you do not wish to walk at all, there is a community bus service from the station every 20 minutes with the fare of only 100 yen. Also, the hotel runs hourly free shuttle bus service to Ikebukuro station on Sat. and Sundays. There is a shuttle service (3000 yen) from Narita Airport, too, but it only runs every few hours.

No longer the Four Seasons we used to loveThe Four Seasons at Chinsanzo was one of our favourite hotels. I used to tell friends that during my first stay in 1996 the hotel gym instructor loan me his personal sneakers so I could work out at the hotel gym and gave me a pair of disposable trunks so I can swim. My wife and I were engaged during our stay 9 years ago. The hotel was rebranded Chinsanzo Hotel in 2013. We thought the excellent service we came to love would continue, and decided to stay here. It was not so. We were left sorely disappointed. The disappointment started upon arrival. No bell staff to take our luggage. I had to go to the concierge to get trolley and help. Next come all the hidden charges. Want a garden view? USD30 a night - no more complimentary upgrades. More ridiculous is the charge of USD42 a person a night for the use of the swimming pool. Which five+ star hotel does that? Complimentary taxi to the train or subway station? Gone. The concierge used to help get Disneyland tickets with no charge - no longer. The hotel remains the same cleanliness, but you can see subtle cost cuts and compromises. Example: The stationary at the desk were of lower grade. Even the smiles and calling you by name are now less frequent. You just feel that the perfectionist Four Seasons quality is gone.Shame. At this rate, this would likely be our last stay.This used to be a special place for me and my wife. Now it is just another hotel. So long Four Seasons at Chinsanzo. You shall be missed.

Stayed at the Chinsanzo on our first night in Tokyo before going to Osaka. We took the Narita Express to Ikebukuro then a taxi to the hotel. About 1.5 hours to get there but the travel was worth it..the hotel check in was smooth, the beds were clean and extremely comfortable especially after a 12 hour flight. The nearest subway station is about 10 minutes walk down a hill and a further 5-10 minutes to restaurants and shops. The hotel gardens with water features are worth a walk through for some lovely pics. Customer service was also excellent. We would definitely stay at the Chinsanzo again.

A beautiful property, set in lovely gardens, we had a 5 night stay here for business. Room was large, spacious, but not clean. The hotel is not cheap, and they charge you for every tiny incremental thing. We had breakfast included in our room rate for 3,000 yen each day. In selecting the american breakfast, I asked to have a little cheese scrambled in my eggwhites. After consuming the breakfast, they came by with a charge slip for an additional 330 Yen for adding cheese. They don't refill the toiletries voluntarily. You may be completely out of shampoo, but need to always request, as they seem pretty tight on refilling anything. While I confirmed at the time of checkin the rate for the room was inclusive of two adults they tried to charge me extra when I checked out. Upon check out, examine your bill closely. It took them 30 minutes to resolve the bill that they had added an addtional $80 USD / night in charges from the originally contracted rate. They operate by strict rules and hierarchy, so the service is not what I would consider 5 star, they do not operate with the customer experience in mind, but rather their P&L/balane sheet. I would not stay here again. Value for money is just not there.

(this used to be the 4 seasons)The hotel has a very pretty garden which is actually a small Japan all in one place with pagoda, shrine, many sculptures, waterfall, and more. Many rooms have view on that garden, and it's fantastic.The staff spoke near perfect English and was very helpful.But look at it as a destination, some place you'd like to stay at and use the facilities. If your plan is to visit Tokyo a lot, this hotel is inconvenient due to its distance from public transport.Bed: very goodAC: very goodNoise: quietLocation: not great. It's hard to get to via trains or metro. By far the easiest is to take a cab to/from ikebukuroInternet: wireless in the roomEnglish: staff spoke excellent english

Had a 5 night stay due to a conference located at the plaza next to the hotel. The rate paid was very reasonable due to conference group rate. Best feature of this hotel is its beautiful garden behind which is great for photo opportunities. With the garden and banquet rooms, the hotel does tons of weddings, with 20-35 weddings during the spring weekend I stayed there. The room itself is also very nicely furnished, with a large bedroom, and huge marbled bathroom by Japanese hotel standard. Couple minuses: Check in/out area is quite small so during busy hours guests must wait in line to be taken care of. The other drawback is the location is not convenient to using public transport, esp JR, since the closest metro station Edogawabashi is about 15 mins walk. The hotel stated 10 min. but that's only to the underground entry point, and then it's another 350m walk to the turnstile area. It's okay walk if going down from hotel during non summer times, but it will be a heavy workout walking up hill back to the hotel in the heat. The only other option is to take a taxi to the JR station Mejiro, or to take the bus #61 which stops serving quite early around 10pm on the weekend.Overall, it was a pleasant stay.Tip: Kagurazaka is a nice find this time for me to get a very nice dinner. It is only one stop from the hotel at Iidabashi station. From hotel the taxi ride is about 1000yen.

A japanese relative booked a room for me at this hotel. I have stayed in Tokyo many times but had never visited Bunkyo. From the nearest tube station the directions to the hotel were a bit confusing, but as the locals are always very helpful we managed to find the hotel without any trouble. The hotel is very grand and charming and the rooms are amazing with lovely L'Occitane products! I would highly reccomend a walk around the gardens, they are absolutely immaculate and beautiful. They even have staff hand picking weeds out of the lawn! We also experienced the afternoon tea which was very delightful.Breakfast was a little disappointing, with very limited choice and very small portions, but overall it definately felt like a 5 star experince!

A perfectly lovely 5-night stay in an unexpectedly charming hotel where traditional values of great hospitality, excellent and very large rooms, and superb staff are clearly valued.Having visited Tokyo many dozens of times, I would not have stayed at the Chinzanso under its former guise as a Four Seasons, partly on grounds of price and partly because I assumed it was quite far out of my way. Had it not been for an amazing travelzoo offer, I would have missed this gem of a hotel with its large and fascinating Japanese garden. With the subway only 10 minutes walk away, a local bus to Mejiro JR station actually stopping at the hotel or a taxi being only around ¥1,000, it links up very conveniently to the public transport system.It is hard to find any fault with the Chinzanso. The TV in the bathroom is a nice ides, but it is badly positioned so you cannot watch it if you are taking a bath; it would have been nice if they had provided small complimentary bottles of water in the room; and the concierge was stumped about the meaning of ‘brunch’ when we tried to locate a restaurant in the city which served brunch on a week-day (admittedly difficult in most cities, especially in Asia). Apart from these tiny issues, the staff could not have been more professional and helpful. Our stay was as the headline reads “close to perfection”. We loved it and were sorry to leave.

It left the Four Seasons system this year. It seems to be striving to extend the traditional Japanese hospitality in dealing with its guests. I think that is for the better. It continues to be an excellent hotel.There are several excellent restaurants in the Chinzanso complex.(The hotel is next to facilities that cater to wedding and other functions.) Four Japanese style restaurants including those specialize in sushi and soba (Japanese noodle). There are first-rate Italian and French restaurants. Next to the lobby is a large and elegant furnished room for afternoon tea and cocktails. One drawback: To access the Tokyo Metro (Subway), the quick way is to take a 5-minute cab ride which will cost about 10 to 15 US dollars.

This is a wonderful hotel, with excellent accommodation in rooms that are spacious by any standards but especially for Tokyo, and fantastic service.The airline had lost my luggage somewhere between Dallas and Chicago, and I'd had to travel on without it: the concierge went to great lengths to assist in having it delivered to my room, making numerous phone calls to the airline and the airport, faxing copies of my passport, etc.Also since April 19, 2013, ATMs at 7-Eleven stores have stopped accepting Mastercard, Maestro and Cirrus cards issued outside of Japan. Similarly, international ATMs across Japan, including postal ATMs, have stopped accepting Maestro cards with EMV chips. This makes it fiendishly difficult for foreigners to withdraw cash in Japan and as Japan is very much a cash society, having no ready money seriously cramps your style. Fortunately the hotel was very willing to provide me with cash in exchange for a credit card payment.The Japanese restaurnat Miyuki serves delicious, if expensive (JPY3,000), Japanese breakfasts. There are several restaurants in the hotel, including one French and one Italian, as well as traditional Japanese buildings in its extensive gardens serving kaiseki, soba and sushi dishes. Currently, an all you can eat Spring buffet is on special offer for JPY9,500.The gardens are a marvel, and if you have time do take the free guided tour. They contain various antique statues and sculptures

We used a Travelzoo voucher for a 3 night stay here and it was an amazing end to our holiday. We got the room for a fraction of the full cost and in fact it was the cheapest place we stayed in our whole Japan trip. The hotel was immaculately clean and the staff were attentive and friendly. The best part was the bed which was easily the nicest bed i have ever slept in! The nearest station was a short 5 minute walk but it may be a bit difficult to get to with luggage as its on a hill. We used the spa area once and this was just as nice as the rest of the hotel. Very clean and copious amounts of fluffy towels at your disposal. Only downside was that we couldn't afford to eat any of the restaurants. Room service was also extortionate. £70 for a burger and pizza! If you walk to the subway station though there are lots of cheap places to eat.Value with the voucher was amazing but there is no way i would pay full price for a room here. I would expect free breakfast, free spa etc for that price.

My husband found this hotel, reading reviews on 5 star hotels in Tokyo. I, honesty, was not very happy that he changed our hotel reservations and booked 2 nights in this hotel. We were informed that the hotel was not close to an underground station, and the best thing was to take a taxi. Which we did. Check-in and luggage handling, smooth as silk. Beautiful hotel, lobby and rooms. Due to renovations we received an upgrade to a 55m2 room which is huge in Tokyo. Beautiful room with view on Tokyo. Great bed, very nice bathroom with a shower and a bath.In the morning we decided to take the breakfast in on of the restaurants. They do not serve breakfast buffet. The breakfast menu was fine but more fancy than to fill an empty stomach and rather expensive for what it is. The hotel is located on a hill so to join the underground takes you +/- 5 minutes (we walk a lot) upwards about 10 minutes but it is a very nice small road with almost no traffic. On our last day we decided to visit the hotel garden and we regretted that we did not do that earlier. Very beautiful gardens and so very peaceful. We really loved the hotel and I just can say that I am happy that it is not a Four Seasons anymore, otherwise we could not afford a hotel like this.

After six visits to Japan over the last 15 years I was ready to try a five star hotel, and when the Travelzoo deal showed up in September of 2012 we jumped on the offer. Hotel Chinzanso Tokyo is set on a hillside that was called Camelia Hill until 1878 when prince Aritomo Yamagata purchased it and named it Chinzanso. The gardens that he and later owners established are there for all to see and enjoy, not just hotel guests. This is one of the nicest gardens attached to a hotel that I have ever seen! The camellias and cherry trees were in full bloom for our visit. The rest of the garden sights like the three story pagoda that is around 500-600 years old, are worth noting too. The garden lists the “Ten Scenic Spots at Chinzanso” that are all worth seeing. I loved the little statues found along the garden path that I called “Japanese garden gnomes”. The sacred tree of the garden is about 500 years old and stands magnificently towards the bottom end of the garden close to the soba restaurant. They also have a stone lantern from around the 12th century. As if the garden isn’t enough of a reason to stay at Chinzanso we found the room, restaurants, and staff to be excellent. Our room was large by Japanese standards, and in excellent condition. The large bathroom had a tub and separate shower as well as L’Occitane toiletries. We were given room number 1001 which had great views of both the gardens and the city of Tokyo. We found the location of the hotel to be much quieter than any other we had stayed at in Tokyo. I had read in previous reviews online that the hotel is kind of far from restaurants and shopping, but we found that the restaurants in the hotel and nearby were very good and many to choose from. The concierge told us about a nearby 175 year old Unagi restaurant that was Michelin rated and quite good. The train station is a 15 minute walk and the Metro is 10 minutes walk from the hotel. Or you can take a taxi for 710 Yen. The hotel is serviced by the Friendly Airport Limousine bus from Narita Airport, and is a good way to and from the hotel. All in all I can’t think of any other place I could recommend more than this hotel for comfort, and service. We will never forget the service from the concierge desk just hours before we checked out. We had lost our camera two days before, but when we were packing up to leave the room my wife found a taxi reciept from the ride we had taken the day the camera was lost. On a whim we had the concierge call the taxi company to see if the camera had been turned in. It had, but they had sent it to the police lost and found. The concierge called the police, but they couldn’t find it so the concierge called the taxi company back, found the camera and got it to us an hour before we left for the airport. Now that is great service.

This used to be a 4 seasons hotel for 20 years and the contract expired and not renewed. From a service perspective, it does not need to be a 4 Seasons. Service is impeccable. I went with my family and while a visit to the garden and the soba restaurant is a must that is a one day activity at most. The hotel is far from the very practical and absolutely necessary train network(closest being Mejiro) and a bus is a bit of a waste of time and a taxi ride is about 800-1000 yen. Restaurant and even breakfast is over priced.

Stayed here for 3 nights in a King Superior Room. We arrived via Mejiro JR station and took a taxi which cost JPY980 to the hotel. You could also take a bus for JPY200 from across the road heading right from the entrance of Mejiro station. It is about 10 mins, dropping you across the road from the hotel, along the same road. Check in was swift and efficient and the receptionist who assisted us was very well versed in English. We were escorted and assisted with our luggage to the room and shown the functionality and layout of the room, which was a nice touch. The room was large by Japan standards, about the size of a mid-size room by Australian standards. Unfortunately, it felt that the furnishing and interior designs are beginning to date and carpet within our room was quite worn. Western style bathroom that was also large, with a bath tub and separate shower and toilet. There was a small TV in the bathroom too. Amenities provided was Loccitane and very luxurious to use. Towels, shower pressure and other toiletries were excellent. Turndown service was provided but no bottled water or chocolates like many other hotels would provide, alongside the set up of possibly yukata and/or slippers.There were limited English channels like most hotels in Japan, but the room on the 14th floor with an excellent view of the city, with views to the Tokyo Skytree as well as the Tokyo Tower, which lights up beautifully at night. The complex of the hotel is large, with about 8-10 restaurants which we did not have the opportunity to try. The gardens of the hotel was a highlight, but was not as large and as trimmed as I thought it would be. 30 mins was more than enough to go through the gardens. Lots of wedding does take place there. Concierge was helpful on occasions, on another occasions, I was less impressed because the staff member did not provide the local dining options when asked and said there was almost none, when in fact after I turned over the page of the local map, a whole list was printed on it in English. In addition, when asked about whether all the buses from Mejiro station would stop at the hotel, she said, "I think so," which was unconvincing for a non-local. However, on another occasion, I had another staff member assisted me with booking a bus from Sapporo airport in Hokkaido to my destination there, and everything worked seamlessly, which I was very thankful for. Buses to Mejiro station did not appear to run until about 2pm onwards, which I found inconvenient. On the other hand, it's an easy downhill walk of 350m to the Edogawabashi subway station, and just a little of a good hike back to the hotel on return. Buses arrival and departure time are as reliable as the trains from experience. Overall, our stay was pleasant enough but it would have been much nicer an experience if promotional material, signage including bus timetable to Mejiro station, spa menu, restaurant specials were available more comprehensively in English. The staff overall had an adequate command of English and appears professional, but it would be nice to find the balance between professionalism and warmth as I did not feel the genuine warm Japanese hospitality come across consistently through all staff members, as I have encountered in other hotels in Japan.

Great hotel, the location is probably the least attractive thing about this hotel.Hotel is a short stroll to the closest metro station which is fine. But if you wanting to duck back for a quick rest or drop off your shopping, it can be an issue due to logistical reasons.Very nice staff, it was a relatively easy check in and check out. An airport shuttle stops right outside the hotel so it's is very convenient.Bathroom was the highlight for me, spacious, clean and the amenities were very nice. The view of Tokyo skyline was amazing too.Definitely will recommend it to others if they don't mind the hike.

We stayed at this hotel in Feb 2013 for 3 nights. We had been here 5 years earlier, when it was still the Four Seasons; on Jan 1, 2013 it rebranded as the Hotel Chinzanso. This hotel is absolutely luxurious and has a superb staff - and I use that word to compare this hotel's staff to the typically-excellent Japanese hotel staffs. The property is designed to be a luxury experience. Our room was the best we've had anywhere in the entire country during our 8 years of annual or 2x/year travel to Japan. We ate at the hotel's Japanese restaurant one night which was simply superb - the service and food both there quite literally amazed us. We had drinks and desert one evening at the hotel bar and were treated royally. We used the concierge who was excellent, and the baggage staff to both receive our bags several days in advance of our arrival, as well as ship bags to the airport and another city in Japan. All in all, this place is awesome.Don't miss the garden on the property. Its full of historic statues and the 3 story pagoda, collected from around the country by a high-ranking official in the 1800s. One of the statues on the property dates from the mid 1600s! The garden is a serene walk in the center of Tokyo, but sits right outside the hotel. Beautiful and relaxing.The one negative about the hotel is its location: we use the subway and trains almost exclusively when in Tokyo, and this hotel is a good 10 minute walk to the nearest station. And that station is not near anything a tourist would want to do, making the hotel a bit out of the way. But that's a minor tradeoff for the truly excellent value at the rates we've seen online (high-$200USD/night).All in all, we think this place is a steal at the current high-$200s (USD) rates we've seen online. This kind of property/service combo is typically experienced at the $450-$600/night range. We're guessing that they are having to lower the price because its not branded "Four Seasons" any longer, but believe me - this place is every bit like the Four Seasons was. If you like to be treated like royalty, enjoy the feeling of being a VIP, and find luxury accommodations up your alley, this hotel should be on your list.

We stayed in this hotel with a special discounted deal, so for the price we paid it was a beautiful big hotel room, and access to its onsen was great. However, it's not a very welcoming, cozy place, none of the restaurants or common areas are very appealing for lounging around with a book in. The one exception is the lounge area near the spa, and if you pay for access to the spa/onsen you get complimentary coffee in the mornings in the lounge. The restaurants were very expensive but there are other options near by. Bit out of the centre of things but access is easy by train and bus. It was nice, but I think for the price you pay, you could find somewhere with more convinience or more charm elsewhere.
